Prime Rupert, B.C., June 10, 1942.

The Director:

On Saturday May 30th Dr. Barclay and I left Vancouver and visited...........

CARIBOO MISSION ROMAN CATHOLIC SCHOOL.

With Agent Christie we visited the above mentioned school, met Father Murphy and some of his staff. The school buildings are old and I believe somewhat of a fire hazard. No evidence of fire escapes, and electric wiring not of the best.

The dormitories were found to be crowded, but clean and tidy. There is no Infirmary and at the time of our visit the pupils were recovering from an epidemic of Scarlet Fever. Under conditions as were found at this school, it must be nearly impossible to control such epidemics. Two mild cases of Trachoma were seen and the Nursing Sister advised treatment should be given.

Drugs were neatly kept and in good order.

W.L. Falconer, M.D.
Asst. Supt. Medical Services.

Re: Repairs, Cariboo Residential School.

Williams Lake, B.C.
August 25th, 1942.

Dear Sir:

Father Murphy, former Principal of the Cariboo Indian Residential School sent a letter, copy of which is enclosed asking for storm windows for the Convent and Kitchen, fir flooring for the boys' dining hall and cement for a basement floor in the kitchen building.

I understand these buildings belong to the Church and I am unaware how the Department looks upon contributing to the upkeep but there is no doubt that the supplies asked for are urgently required.

The building is old and understand very cold in the winter and there is no doubt that storm windows would make a very great difference besides conserving fuel.

The floor in the boys' dining hall is also in poor condition, being completely worn through in places.

Your obedient servant,

Wm. Christie,
Acting Indian Agent.

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Vancouver, B.C.

Williams Lake, B.C.,
February 18, 1944.

Major D.M. MacKey, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

On a recent visit to Cariboo Indian Residential School, the laundry situation was gone into, and I found that with existing facilities, it is absolutely impossible to keep the children's clothing clean.

One whole day per week is occupied by all the girls in washing clothes. The following day is taken up with ironing, and when the sheets from the boys' beds have to be washed, and their overalls, two days have to be spent in washing. Under this arrangement, I do not think that the sheets are changed more than once a month, and the boys' overalls, on various occasions, appear to be quite dirty.

Father McGrath is quite aware of this situation; in fact, it was one of the first things he went into after coming to the Cariboo School. He made inquiries at Vancouver from Stanley Brock, Limited, and received a quotation on a 36 x $4 2-compartment belt driven Monarch Wood Washer, which was quoted at $713.00, f.o.b. Vancouver. The school, however, has never had the money available to purchase this machine.

I understand that most of the other Indian Residential Schools are equipped with a suitable sized washing machine with all the other equipment such as an extractor for drying the clothes, and electric ironer. I am not aware whether these washing machines are supplied by the Department for the other Residential Schools or not, but I would imagine that where the Department has put up the buildings, that they have also equipped same.

Despite the fact that the Cariboo Indian School buildings belong to the Oblate Mission, I feel quite certain that this expenditure for a washing machine would do much to improve the situation from a health standpoint. It stands to reason during the past epidemic that a terrific amount of washing would have been required to keep things as they should be.

While it is no doubt advisable that these Indian

(over)
Girls should know how to do the laundry work without any of the modern conveniences, the amount of laundry that should be done in an establishment such as this would take up far too much time for the girls, to the detriment of their academic and other activities, which makes this institution less like a school and more like a penal institution.

As I said before, Father McGrath realizes this situation only too well, but apparently the funds are not available as far as the school is concerned, and I would strongly recommend that the Department consider the purchase of the washing machine as indicated above, and also one Canadian Underdriven Solid Curb Extractor, price for which can be obtained from Stanley Brock Limited, Vancouver, B.C.

Father McGrath advises me that he will find a suitable power to operate this outfit.

I understand a priority is necessary to get this equipment, but no doubt same could be obtained for an institution of this kind.

W. Christie,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa,
March 25, 1944.

EX'D.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

I have your letter of the 17th instant, submitting a request for laundry machinery costing approximately $1600 for the Cariboo Indian Residential School.

When submitting the estimates for the fiscal year 1944-45 Indian Agent Christie requested $500 for laundry machinery for this school and this amount is included in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1944-45. As you know, the Cariboo School is a Church-owned building and funds for repairs, improvements and purchase of new equipment are provided in a special appropriation and we are only allowed to expend at such schools the amount actually included in the appropriation. As you are also aware, our estimates for 1944-45 were prepared last November, at which time, as stated above, we included the amount requested; namely, $500. You will, therefore, realize that it is through no fault of this office that consideration was not given to providing the larger amount but, in view of the conditions mentioned above, it will not be possible for the Department to consider an expenditure of $1615 for this equipment during the fiscal year 1944-45.

I feel it is advisable for you to point out again to Indian Agent Christie that the requirements at his agency must be anticipated. If the requirements are not brought to our attention...
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Christie's letters of the 18th and 25th ultimo requesting the provision of laundry machinery for the Cariboo Indian Residential School.

I have made local enquiry regarding the cost of such an installation and would advise that the prices are approximately as follows:

1. Washer $713.00 36x54 2 compartment Monarch A wood washer belt drive
2. Extractor 20" $700.00
3. Shafting, etc. $150.00
4. Freight $50.00

$1613.00

As pointed out by Mr. Christie, the girl pupils of the school are at present supplying the labour for carrying out this laundry work by hand and, in my opinion, the task is far beyond their physique and likely to result in medical costs much in excess of the cost of the appropriate equipment. While the school is not owned by the Department, I would recommend in the interests of the pupils' health the provision of suitable equipment as suggested above. There are 121 pupils attending this school.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Enc.
Williams Lake, B.C.
February 25, 1944.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

Your file 215-16-1511

In reply to your letter of the 23rd inst., the question of a power unit to operate the proposed laundry equipment for the Cariboo Indian Residential School was discussed with Father McGrath.

The present Delco plant at the School has not capacity enough for this equipment, but, having in mind the proposed rural electrification scheme after the war, Father McGrath contemplates an electric motor as the ideal power unit.

For the present, however, he will use the farm tractor which is also used for other belt work around the school. Approximately $150.00 would have to be spent on shafting, pulleys, etc. but the installation of this equipment is a comparatively simple matter.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Your File 160-0-5

I wish to refer to your letter of March 23rd, regarding laundry machinery for the Cariboo Indian Residential School.

Mr. Indian Agent Christie has discussed this matter with the Reverend Father McGrath who advises that, if the Department are willing to contribute $500.00 towards the cost of a washer, the School would subscribe the balance required for a washer and the necessary shafting to operate same.

If this suggestion meets with your approval, an item will be entered in the 1945-46 Estimates for the extractor and other necessary equipment.

[Signature]

For D. M. Mackay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

May 18, 1944.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

Your file 215-16

With further reference to your letter of March 29th, regarding laundry equipment for the Cariboo Indian Residential School; Purchase Order No. 23902, Encumbrance No. 206 was recently issued by the Department and a 30" x 48" washer has been supplied by Stanley Brock Ltd., of Vancouver, costing $440.00.

Fr. McGrath is now anxious to get an extractor and I believe Stanley Brock has a suitable machine available. Fr. McGrath is prepared to purchase this machine immediately and asked me to write the Department to see if it would be possible for them to reimburse the School to the extent of the cost of this equipment, out of next year's appropriation.

In your letter of March 29th it was suggested that I place an item in the 1945-46 estimates to cover purchase of an extractor and other laundry equipment in 1945-46. However it would seem preferable that all the equipment that goes with the washer should be installed at one time instead of piece-meal and if the School is prepared to finance the purchase and installation of the other equipment immediately, in the interests of efficiency, it might be possible for the Department to authorize a grant out of the 1945-46 appropriation to reimburse them for this expenditure.

Will you kindly advise me as soon as possible if you think the Department could give any such guarantee.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.

I have received a letter from Reverend Father McGrath, Principal of the Cariboo Indian Residential School, a copy of which is enclosed, in which he refers to the drop in the earnings of the school for the last quarter, the enrollment being some twenty-one children below the quota of one hundred and twenty allowed for this school, and requesting that the Department favourably consider payment of the per capita grant on the basis of the full quota in order to assist the school to meet operating costs. I fail to see how this could be done in view of the regulations governing the payment of the per capita grant.

The Principal lists two items on which outlays have recently been made from school funds, namely, renewal of flooring in the laundry $385.00, and laundry extractor $500.00, which expenditures probably would not have been incurred had the decline in enrollment been anticipated. If it were possible for the Department to reimburse the school for these outlays it would considerably help them through the present difficulty. Father McGrath is doing his best to carry on under very difficult circumstances and is deserving of any assistance in this respect that the Department is in a position to extend.

I am afraid that the Oblate Order is going to find it extremely difficult to operate this school without loss even on the basis of a full attendance owing to the very high cost of maintaining in reasonably good repair the very old group of buildings comprising the school. Dear Major MacKay:

Thank you very much for your kind
rememberance of us at Christmas. I sincerely hope that you had a
pleasant Christmas and that the New Year will be a happy one for you.
The children here enjoyed themselves very much. For the staff it
was as usual a very busy and tiring time but it was worth it all
to see the children so happy. Things are back to normal again now.

I sent in our Quarterly Report a few days ago for the December
Quarter. As you know our attendance has been down so far this
year and our reports showed only 99 children instead of our normal
quota of 120. Our Missionaries have tried to round up the necessary
number but there are many yet of school age whom the parents want
to keep home for another year. It seems to have become the custom
up here in very many cases to keep the children home till they are
around 10 and 11 years old. That makes it very difficult to get
them into the higher grade before the time comes for them to leave
at 16. However I am hoping that we will gradually be able to educate
the parents along the right lines. What is worrying me about the
last Report is that our Per Capita Grant will be reduced in accordance
with the lower attendance and if there was ever a time that we need
our full Per Capita Grant, it is now. We have put quite a lot of money
into repairs and upkeep of the buildings. We have had to raise the
salaries of our Instructors. It cost us $385.00 to renew the
Laundry building floor and $500.00 for the extractor. This has all
left us not only broke but a couple of hundred dollars in the hole.
This in itself is not unusual but if $900.00 is taken off our
Per Capita Grant for the last quarter it will make things pretty
awkward. So I would ask you if you would be good enough to recommend
at Ottawa that we be given our full Per Capita. I have also written
to Mr. Christie and I am sure that you will both see our position.

I neglected to mention that there is also a bill of some $2000.00
owing the Mission for food and wood which we will be unable to pay.
This was also the case last year. Hoping you will be able to help
us out and wishing you again a Very Happy New Year, I remain.

Yours very truly,

J.M. McGrath O.M.I.

Further, it has become quite evident that the Department will have to make decision—and the sooner the better—as to whether they wish to continue this residential school, in which case provision should be made as soon as possible after the War for the erection of a modern building. At the same time, there are some outlying reserves where a day school is not feasible. It has occurred to me, however, that with the establishment of day schools in this and other agencies, the pupilage of the Kamloops Indian Residential School and the Lejac School would be reduced, and thus provision might be made for children from these outlying reserves at the institutions mentioned. QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING MARCH 31, 1945, ON WILLIAMS LAKE AGENCY

EDUCATION

Inspector McArthur visited the Cariboo Indian School during March and his report has no doubt been received by the Department by this time. Having been called out to the Chilcotin, I could not accompany Mr. McArthur on his inspection, but following his report, I paid a visit to the School some days later, and paid particular attention to the matters on which complaint was made and had the fire alarm sounded.

The children were very orderly in getting out of the buildings and were all out in under one minute. Fr. McGrath had already taken the locks off all the escape doors, the subject of a very legitimate complaint by Inspector McArthur. It is felt, however, that Mr. McArthur has exaggerated regarding the condition of the boys' dormitory, which has been painted up and is very considerably improved since last year. The improvements in this school since it opened last September have been very considerable, and are as follows:

Equipment: Laundry equipment, consisting of power washer and extractor, saving much time for the girls and improving hygienic conditions.

Vocational: Manual Training classes have been organized. Also Calf Club and Potato Club.

Recreational: The Pro-Rec. program has been continued. Three Skating rinks were maintained during the past winter, two for the boys and one for the girls. Hockey games were organized and matches played with boys from the Williams Lake white school.

A boys' pipe and drum band has been organized by Brother MacDonald and is making good progress. Brother MacDonald, who commenced duties as disciplinarian last September, has been a great asset to the school, and there has been only one occasion of truancy since last September. The morale amongst the boys was very low during 1943-44 and a number of boys were expelled in June, so that I consider Brother

(over)
Brother MacDonald has done a wonderful job considering the bad feeling amongst the boys which had to be overcome.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.

Re: Improvements at Williams Lake School, B.C.
Attention: Mr. F. Phelan.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

As I mentioned to you yesterday, I am just back from an inspection tour of the seven Indian Residential Schools of British Columbia, conducted by the Reverend Oblate Fathers.

Whilst I found all these institutions in fairly good physical condition, the war years have no doubt left their mark and considerable repair, both within and without, has now become essential. The equipment also shows a good deal of wear and some of it must be replaced this year.

For the purpose of clarity, I think it will be better for me to write you a separate letter for each school.

Williams Lake School is one of the oldest in B.C. and is church-owned. It may have, for the above reason, been more neglected than government-owned institutions, although I fail to see any justification for this neglect. After all, if the church has seen fit to invest large sums of money in the building of these schools, this latter fact should be an extra reason for receiving special help and consideration from the Department.

The first and most needed improvement in this institution is a central heating plant which, we believe, would cost in the neighborhood of $20,000.00 and I hereby ask that this amount be provided for in the 1947-48 estimates.
The B.C. Electric Power will very likely build a power line along the Cariboo Highway either this Fall or next Spring and if this takes place, as it has already been promised, a sufficient amount should be included in the coming estimates to install its services in the school. We believe that this service will cost around $3,000.00.

The school is still using ice for refrigeration purposes with the consequent loss of food. With B.C. Electric Power, a frigidaire must be installed and should also be provided for in the coming estimates.

The above are the principal big items needed for this school, but the following items should also be added to the above list:

1. Hardwood floors in the boys' recreation room and in the dining-room for both boys and girls.

2. A new washing machine sufficient to take care of the needs of the present pupilage, with the increase that will be needed in the immediate future.

3. The sewing machines of the school are all quite old and three new machines are necessary.

4. The library should be increased to the necessary size both in quantity and variety, to answer the needs of the pupils.

5. The present pupilage is 123 but should be increased to 140, as the school population is much larger than the latter number and must be provided for if we do not want the children of the present generation to grow up in ignorance.

The above is quite a programme of improvements for the one school, but the Department must approve it as by doing so, it will keep in operation an institution which it would cost at least $300,000.00 to replace.

Very truly yours,

J.G. Plourde, O.M.I.

Very Rev. and Dear Father,

We were all sorry to hear of Father Birch's illness and we hope he has recovered by now.

In regard to the electric plant I have not heard anything further from the Indian Agent or the Department. Our position at present in regard to electricity is very unsatisfactory. We are operating a 2 kilowatt, direct current, 110 volt generator driven by a gasoline engine. It is an old rebuilt plant. Since November it has cost us between $4. and $5. a day to run this plant. We use it for lights only and cut our lights down to the very minimum. As you noticed while you were here our lights are very poor. For lights alone we require 3½ kws, but this plant generates only 2 kws, as a result the voltage often drops to 85 or 90. We have no electric appliances or motors. The plant is a great fire hazard, being 110 volts direct current and a gasoline engine which has to be kept running all night. I said it was a rebuilt plant, but apparently the oil seals were not renewed or could not be obtained. As a result the oil has continually been running out of the crank case, much of it runs along the shaft and is splashed around by the fly wheel. I mention this because the floor and wall being saturated with oil add so much more to the fire hazard. If we had a diesel plant the cost of operation would drop to about $0.50 a day. We should have a 5 kw, 110 volt, alternating current plant and should be equipped to charge 32 volt batteries for night lights, this would shorten the daily operation of the engine by about 6 hours.

So far there is no indication that the B.C. Power Commission intends to supply power to 150 Mile House from Williams Lake.

Diesel Electric Plants are sold here by the Interior Distributors, Kamloops, B.C.

Hoping it is possible to obtain a more suitable electric plant in the near future,

I am yours in J. & M.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I have just returned after being three months in the West, during which time I visited all our B.C. Indian Schools with the exception of Kakawis. Unfortunately an attack of bronchitis prevented me from taking that trip.

I feel that I should draw your attention to the hard struggle that most of these schools are experiencing in order to make ends meet from the financial angle, and I am respectfully asking you to submit
this matter to the Department for their very urgent consideration.

Williams Lake School in particular is in a very bad way. Already there is a large overdraft at the Bank, even though all the salaries on the part of the Fathers and Brothers have been eliminated. With the cost of living mounting to such high proportions it is impossible to finance a school on the present per capita grant. I am not in a position to carry the overdraft that I can see will be on the books by the end of the present school year. It seems to me that, unless some financial assistance is forthcoming to help to meet this crisis, we shall be obliged to close down the school.

There is another point upon which I beg you to give particular attention, and that is the electric plant now working in Williams Lake school. During the days that I spent there it was practically impossible to read by the light produced. The enclosed letter from the Principal, which has reached me since my return, speaks far more eloquently than I can upon the haunting fear that I had during my stay, namely should fire break out.

With reference to Mr. Phelan's Army Signals message of September 17th and correspondence in connection with the purchase of a lighting plant for the Cariboo Indian Residential School, I regret the delay in securing information with respect to the school's requirements and quotations on a suitable plant, and even yet I am not in a position to make a definite recommendation. I am enclosing for your information a copy of Mr. C. F. Webb's letter of August 18th and quotations from the following listed firms:

(1) Vivien Engine Works Ltd., - 18 kw. $4,257.00
A letter dated September 12th from the Company amending their original delivery date on this model to eight weeks and advising of a net reduction of $150.00 in their quotation if a complete steel sub-base is not required is also enclosed.

(2) Finning Tractor & Equipment Co. Ltd.
Model D4400, 20 kw. $4,760.00
Delivery 5 to 6 months

I am of the opinion that we should not consider purchase of a secondhand plant.

(3) Lipsett Engine and Manufacturing Co. Ltd.
Sheppard diesel generating set. The Company quotes on a 15 kw model and an 18 kw model, but in view of the known electrical energy requirements at the school it is not considered that we should secure a model of less than 18 kws.
18 kw model... $3,393.00
Delivery three weeks after receipt of order
It should be noted that although earliest delivery is obtainable on the Sheppard diesel plant, this plant is manufactured in the United States and comparatively little is known with regard to its operating efficiency whereas the Vivian outfit is manufactured in Vancouver and units manufactured by this Company are giving satisfactory service in this and other Departments. I have been endeavouring to secure information regarding the Sheppard diesel electric units and have recently written to the Marine Division of the Department of Transport, Victoria, who have a Sheppard unit located at Bull Harbour. I also arranged for inspection of Sheppard diesel electric sets and parts located at the Lipsett Engine and Manufacturing Company, Vancouver, by an official of the Service Department, Civil Aviation Division, Dept. of Transport, Mr. Dennis' letter of September 15th in this connection being enclosed.

With reference to your letter of September 17th requesting information on our Sheppard Diesel unit now operating at our Bull Harbour Radio Station, we are rather hesitant to offer any definite opinions one way or the other due to the fact that this unit has only been recently installed. We are rather perturbed over your statement concerning the design of the lubricating and fuel injection systems. In this regard we can only state that so far no troubles have been encountered whatever with our unit.

Should there be no immediate need for purchasing your unit we would suggest that you defer your decision for approximately two weeks when we will be able to give you a detailed operating report of this unit covering approximately one month's operation.

Our determining factor in choosing a Sheppard was the fact that they are of simple design; compact, easily transported, low fuel consumption and absolutely reliable and rugged from all reports we could obtain up to the time of purchase. During a short test run in our shop prior to installation this engine proved equal to all our requirements. The voltage regulation is extremely good. Repairs can be made by relatively untrained personnel and the engine maintained without undue technical knowledge being required.

Reference caterpillars, we have one installed, a 15 HP, at our Estevan station which has given us very reliable service. This is a proven design and consequently a safe
purchase. We have no real fault to find with this engine other than they do require a technical man to maintain. Over and above the diesel end you have also a gasoline engine which adds to the problem of storing gasoline etc. which our Department is attempting to eliminate entirely due to the hazards connected with this fuel.

Our Vivian Diesel is an old engine and has been in service for 15 years or more. During that time it has been quite reliable. There is one weakness, however, in this unit in that the intermediate and main bearings require renewing at least every 12 months or sooner. The manufacturers claim that this is quite normal and cannot recommend anything to rectify this trouble.

For further information on the Sheppard we would suggest you write to the Nelson Bros. Fish Packers, c/o the Mechanical Superintendent. This firm has a number of Sheppards in use of all sizes. I am sure they could give you a much better report than we can at this time. However should you care to receive a copy of the operating report we are compiling we would be only too pleased to send you a copy.

Kindly advise us further on this matter.

Yours faithfully,

"W. J. Bowerman"

Dear Colonel Neary:

I sent my Nightletter yesterday to you or Mr. Phalen, not knowing whether or not you were back in Ottawa. Before I left the Capital, you were out of the city. By the time this letter is in your hands, you will have given your kind attention to the matter of the new electric plant at the Indian School at Williams Lake, of this I feel confident. There is no need for me to picture the many, deplorable consequences of a school without electric light or power. In his wire to me, Fr. Morris said that he had no word of the new plant whatsoever and that he would have to close the school unless one was supplied immediately. The closing of the school would be a calamity that must be avoided at all costs. I am sure we all agree on that. If I am not mistaken, I mentioned the question of the new electric plant and also the water problem to Mr. Phalen, in your absence, some three weeks ago. I feel certain that Mr. Phalen took whatever action he could at once. I have the impression that the new plant was promised some few weeks ago, or longer; is the delay due to lack of this equipment, or some other similar factor over which one has no control? At any rate, I leave the matter in your capable hands, fully confident that you will leave no stone unturned in your willing effort to remedy the deplorable situation that has arisen at Williams Lake Residential school.

At Fort St. John, Bishop Jordan and I had the pleasure of a long conference with the Indian Agent. By this time, you have most probably heard from him. He wishes to erect an Indian Day School at Moberly Lake and to have it in operation by next Fall. He will give you the details. Bishop Jordan and I are very willing and anxious to further the plan and, one of the great difficulties being the supply of a teacher, we have promised one of our Fathers for the task. As a result of our visit to the district, Father Jungbluth the Indian missionary, formerly residing at Fort St. John, will take up his residence at Moberly Lake next month. The erection of a school and the appointment of a teacher will be a great step forward in our common attempt to further improve the status and condition of the Indians in that district. My purpose in mentioning this matter is to endorse the Agent's plan and to confirm what he undoubtedly will tell you of our willing cooperation with him in executing it. We trust that it will be favourably received by you.

I fly to Fort McLeod tomorrow then I will visit Vanderhoof, Lejac etc. and I expect to reach Prince Rupert in about ten days where you may address me c/o The Bishop's House.

With every good wish, I am,

Yours sincerely,

Joseph R. Birch, O.M.I., Provincial.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Reverend Father J.A. Morris, O.M.I.,
Principal of the Cariboo Indian Residential School at
150 Mile House, B.C., has written me with reference to the very
bad financial condition of this school at the present moment.
So that you will have the particulars set out by Father Morris,
I quote from his letter as follows:-

"In view of the increasing financial difficulties
in our work of Indian education at this school I find it
necessary to solicit your help. Our work here in the
Cariboo should be of interest to the present government,
because to a great extent our interests are its interests
also. In addition to this school, there is now a community
at Williams Lake and one at Anaham, both devoted to
education.

"We are in great need of financial assistance right
now. The cost of living has gone up 45% and the Indian
Affairs Branch increased the per Capita Grant by only
17% last year. We need, for this school, an additional
25% increase and should be retroactive to October 1st, 1947,
because we have not been able to meet many of our
obligations since then.

"Compared with other schools our basic per Capita
grant rate is not sufficient. This is not my opinion
alone, but also that of Major Davey, school Inspector
for the Indian Schools of British Columbia. Our basic
per Capita Grant rate is $170.00, which is the same as
the schools on the coast and in the Vancouver area are
getting. Then including the special and emergency grants

...........
Colonel B.F. Neary

February 16, 1948.

"Our rate is $215.00, which is less than some of the schools on Vancouver Island and the coast are getting. Rather than getting less we should be getting more than the schools in those areas are getting, because:

1. Our food bill is almost double what theirs is. This principally on account of the rigor of the climate.

2. Our clothing bill is more than double that of the schools on the coast. Because of the climate more and warmer clothing is needed and because of the fact that the parents supply so little, while on the coast the parents supply a large percentage of their children's clothing.

3. Our freight and transportation in the Cariboo is much higher than elsewhere; e.g., coal is $5.00 or more a ton here than along the C.P.R. or C.N.R. lines or at the coast; oil is 8 or 9 cents more a gallon here than it is at such remote parts of Vancouver Island as Kakawis; bread is at least 4 cents a loaf more here than it is in Vancouver.

"Our buildings are very old and this is another cause of great expense. There are continual and innumerable repairs needed, the buildings are very cold, which all adds up to more expenses in maintenance, repairs and fuel. We need new buildings, which we hope will not be too long delayed. But we need financial assistance immediately.

"Until this year we were able to make up the deficit of the School from the revenue of the ranch, which is owned by the Oblate Fathers, but this year we cannot meet our obligation even with this help. The drain on the ranch has been so great that it too is now operating on an over-draft."

I know that this matter will receive your serious consideration, and I shall appreciate anything you may be able to do to help.

With best personal regards,

Yours faithfully,

Re: Cariboo Indian Residential School

This is a church-owned school and in the current year's appropriation we provided an amount of $5,000 for repairs and improvements to the above mentioned school. An amount of $3,603.65 was expended for the purchase of a lighting plant and in our telegram of December 20th to Major MacKay we advised him that the balance, namely $1,396.35 could be expended for electric wiring which is apparently necessary.

We have a letter from Very Rev. J.R. Birch, O.M.I., Provincial of the Missionary Oblates of Mary Immaculate which reads in part as follows:

"The Cariboo Indian Residential School is still without electric lights, nothing having been done regarding the wiring. There have been many electricians and estimates, but most of them want to do a completely new job of everything, which would run into thousands of dollars. The last individual to give an estimate was from Hume N. Rumble of Vancouver. He said that he would change only what was absolutely necessary to safety, without following the B.C. code. His estimate was $5,000. There is only $1,200 remaining of the special grant to do the work. Therefore, that offer could not be accepted, and now the Principal is endeavouring to find an electrician who will do only what is necessary to get the plant running. He is certainly doing his utmost to try to have the present wiring made safe, without spending more than the amount of money that remains of the grant made for that purpose."
No doubt your office has been in touch with the principal, Reverend Father Morris in connection with the matter, but we would appreciate it if you could communicate with him again with a view to ascertaining if there is anything you can do to assist him in securing someone to do the necessary electric wiring for the amount available in the current year's appropriation.

If you find that you cannot have the electric wiring done you may expend an amount of approximately $600. for the erection of a new chimney and other urgent repairs at this school.

However, if you are successful in arranging for the electric wiring which will involve an expenditure of the amount available in the current year's appropriation, you may arrange for the repairs and new chimneys after April 1st at an approximate cost of $600.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.
February 16, 1948.

Dear Father Birch:

Your letter of the 12th instant with reference to the Cariboo Residential School has been brought to my attention. In the case of church-owned schools, present regulations require that we can only expend the amount actually provided in our appropriation for any one school.

In the current year's appropriation we provided an amount of $5,000. for the Cariboo Residential School and a lighting plant was purchased in October last at a cost of $3,603.65. This left a balance of $1,396.35 which we could expend at the Cariboo School during the current fiscal year.

Former Indian Commissioner MacKay was informed to that effect on December 20, 1947 and presumably Reverend Father Morris has been acting on the authority received from Major MacKay in endeavouring to secure someone to do the necessary electric work.

I am writing today to the present Indian Commissioner, Mr. Arneil, requesting him to co-operate with the Reverend Principal in endeavouring to secure some firm to do the wiring, at least to the extent which funds are available. If this is not possible, Mr. Arneil will be authorized to expend an amount of $600. for the repairs and new chimneys mentioned in the second paragraph of your letter. If the amount is expended for wiring, Mr. Arneil will be advised that the repairs and new chimneys will receive attention immediately after April 1st so that the cost may be charged to our appropriation for the fiscal year 1948-49.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

On the 13th January 1948, I inspected certain buildings at the Cariboo Indian Residential School, near 150 Mile Post Office, Cariboo Road, and the following are my findings:

Father's House:
The chimney required removal of all wood coverings, woodwork must be at least 2 inches from a chimney and the space stopped with metal or filled with lime mortar or asbestos at each floor level and at roof. The three furnaces to be repaired generally; New heavy gauge intake thimbles required for all furnaces and installed at least 18 inches from ceiling, strap hangers to replace any wire used to hold heavy metal pipe between furnace and chimneys.

Gentlemen,

Last October we purchased from Lipsett Engine and Manufacturing Company Limited, 1315 Powell St., Vancouver, B.C., an electric power and lighting unit for the Cariboo Indian Residential School at Williams Lake, B.C. In reply to your letter of the 27th ultimo, respecting the tariff status of an electric power and lighting unit, consisting of a diesel engine and generator, which was purchased from Lipsett Engine and Manufacturing Co. Limited, Vancouver, and cleared through Customs under Vancouver Entries Nos. 10316-A, June 22, 1946, and 40060-A, November 14, 1947. You contend that as the equipment is for the use of the Cariboo Indian Residential School at Williams Lake, B.C., same should be admitted free of duty and exempt from Sales Tax under Tariff Item 696.

In reply, I may advise you that, from information before the Department, the Model 6D Sheppard Diesel Engine, being mechanical equipment of a class or kind not made in Canada, is admissible free of duty under Tariff Item 696, when for the use and by order of the Cariboo Indian Residential School, Williams Lake, B.C., and not for sale.

The 15 K.W. Generator is, however, of a class or kind made in Canada and is not entitled to duty free entry under Tariff Item 696, but is dutiable under Tariff Item 445f at 25% ad valorem, under the Canada-United States Trade Agreement as in effect at the time of importation, notwithstanding the fact that it is for the use of an educational institution.

Articles qualifying for entry under Tariff Item 696 are exempt from the Consumption or Sales Tax. Otherwise, this tax of 5% levied on the duty paid value is applicable.
The Collector of Customs and Excise at Vancouver has been supplied with a copy of this letter.

Yours truly,

Cariboo Indian Residential School.

We have had many representations concerning the need for replacing the above Residential School with a new plant.

Due to our large residential school requirements elsewhere, we have not been able to include a sum in our estimates for the building of a new residential school. You are, of course, aware of the loss by fire during the war of several residential schools, and naturally these replacements have a priority over the Cariboo Residential School.

However, we are aware, from reports received, that a major need at this school is for a new heating system. It has been suggested that a possible solution to this problem would be to take the following steps:

(a) Erect a heating plant in a separate unit, which would handle the present school and which would form the first part of the new residential school.

(b) Erect a new residential school, unit by unit, in the years to come.

The new residential school which we are building at Teslin, Y.T., will be of frame construction and will consist
of the following units:

(1) Administration building.
(2) Girls' Dormitory building.
(3) Boys' Dormitory building
(4) Classroom block
(5) Power house unit.

It would be appreciated if we could have your ideas as to the feasibility of the above suggestion. If you consider the above plan to be workable, we will then approach the Lands and Development Services Branch and request that they prepare the drawings and specifications for such a power unit at the Cariboo Residential School.

Bernard F. Neary,

MACHINE shall be constructed with such characteristics described below, and equipped with such accessories, also described, as are contained in our letter of proposal to which this specification is attached.

CYLINDER (SPOT-WELDED) — Shall be constructed with cylinder sheets, partitions, end-circles and ribs of .050-inch sheet monel.

Cylinder sheets and sides of ribs shall have double embossed perforations leaving smooth, round raised rings on inside of cylinder which shall not injure work being washed. Perforations shall be so spaced as to allow maximum circulation of washing solution.

Cylinder sheets shall be lapped and seams spot-welded. Sheets shall be spot-welded to outwardly projecting flanges of end circles and riveted to outwardly projecting flanges of cast-mechanite metal transmitters. Cylinder gudgeon shall be mechanite metal, renewable type, secured to transmitters by monel cap screws.

OPEN POCKET TYPE — Shall have three perforated ribs, 3¾ inches high, spot-welded to cylinder sheets. Rib strips at ends of ribs shall be spot-welded to ribs and end circles and screwed to transmitter.

Y-POCKET TYPE — Shall have continuous Y-shaped partition of .062-inch sheet monel spot-welded to cylinder sheets and flanges of end circles. Transmitter shall be recessed to receive extensions formed by Y-partition and end circle flanges. Extensions so formed shall be leaded into recesses.

CYLINDER DOOR — Shall be sliding type of heavy sheet monel, with plain perforations. Monel metal door guides, screwed and spot-welded to cylinder sheets, shall assure free and easy movement of doors. Each door shall be equipped with two latch boxes having spring loaded wedge-shaped latch bolts operating in heavy, reversible and renewable latch keepers. Doors shall be arranged to latch in both open and closed positions and shall be reinforced by suitable panel batten spot-welded to door sheet.

TUB — Tub sheets and end heads shall be .043 sheet monel with sheets spot-welded to outwardly projecting flanges of heads. Shall be so arranged that upper portion of tub may be removed to permit cylinder to be taken out.

TUB DOOR — Shall be sliding type of .050 inch monel. Shall be equipped with supply pocket having hinged cover. Door shall operate in monel metal guides spot-welded to tub case. Guides shall be equipped with renewable top strips.

LOADING AND UNLOADING APRON — Shall be sheet monel, hinged to tub at deep side. Shall be arranged to bridge gap between tub case and cylinder during loading and unloading operations.

FRAMES — Shall consist of pressed steel, held together by tie rods at bottom and heavy bar at rear. Shall support cylinder, tub and driving mechanism. Superstructure forming mounting for driving mechanism shall consist of steel angles welded together in a unit and rigidly secured to end frames.

BEARINGS (INTERMEDIATE AND CYLINDER) — Bearings shall be bronze bushings babbitted in cast iron housings. Cylinder bearings shall be so arranged as to prevent bearing lubricant entering cylinder or washing solution entering bearings.

CONNECTIONS — 2-inch water inlet connection shall be furnished in rear of tub case. ¾" steam inlet connection shall be furnished in the bottom of tub case.

OUTLET VALVE — Shall be 4-inch treadle-operated self-cleaning type equipped with renewable flexible valve disc. Locking device on treadle shall lock valve in closed position. Outlet valve shall be enclosed in sheet metal housing to prevent splashing.

GUARD — Drive mechanism and brake shall be fully enclosed by removable type sheet metal guard.

LUBRICATION — Hydraulic gun fittings on bearings. Wick oiler for driving chains.

MOTOR DRIVE ONLY

DRIVE — MOTOR TO CYLINDER — Shall be combination silent and roller chain with tension adjustment. Motor base plate shall be mounted on right hand end of superstructure.

ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT — Motors, controllers and accessories shall conform to applicable sections of National Electrical Manufacturers' Association (NEMA) standards, and shall have ample capacity.
and suitable characteristics to operate machine under specified operating conditions without exceeding allowable temperature rise.

Wiring furnished with machine shall conform to National Electrical Code (NEC) requirements.

**MOTOR—SINGLE SPEED TYPE**—Shall be ball bearing, grease-lubricated, reversing type.

**TWO-SPEED TYPE**—Shall be ball bearing, grease lubricated, reversing type, equipped with transfer switch to obtain either speed.

**CONTROLLER**—Shall be so arranged to assure a uniform number of cylinder revolutions between reversals with but slight difference in either direction of rotation.

Shall be furnished with motor-driven timer and magnetic contactors for reversing washer drive motor, and shall be equipped with overload and undervoltage protection, pilot-circuit fuses, and resistors as required.

**INTERLOCK**—Tub door shall be interlocked electrically so that opening of door shall interrupt motor circuit, set brake, and prevent further movement under power, except for inching.

**OPERATING SWITCHES**—Cylinder motor switch shall be mounted on washer at point convenient for operator with push buttons necessary for normal machine operation. Separate control switch shall be provided for starting and stopping wringer motor.

**BRAKE**—Shall be spring-set, electro-mechanically released, shoe-type; shall stop cylinder movement and maintain cylinder at rest.

**WRINGER EQUIPPED TYPE ONLY**

**WRINGER**—Shall consist of metal frame equipped with two motor-driven reversible rubber rolls with emergency safety release.

Shall have cadmium plated steel apron. Hinged monel metal combination drain board and unloading apron attached to tub case of washer shall divert flow of water back into tub.

Wringer, wringer motor and drive shall be mounted on bracket at left hand side of machine. Assembly shall be mounted so that wringer may be swivelled from a position flat against the end of the machine to its operating position, and shall be locked in either position.

**WRINGER MOTOR**—Shall be geared-head, ball bearing, grease-lubricated, totally enclosed type with individual control for starting and stopping.

**BELT DRIVE ONLY**

**DRIVE**—Shall be through single reduction roller chain from automatic reverse header to cylinder sprocket.

**AUTOMATIC REVERSE HEADER**—Shall consist of three pulleys, two fixed and one loose, driven by flat belts from customer's line shaft.

An automatic worm and cam movement, moving belts alternately from the fast to loose pulleys, shall assure uniform number of cylinder revolutions between reversals with but slight difference in either direction of rotation.

Header shall be arranged so that belts may be shifted manually when required.

**BRAKE**—Shall be manually operated, contracting-band type, with two position lever, ON and OFF.

**WATER-LEVEL GAGE GLASS**—Shall be fitted into one end of tub and indicate height of liquid in cylinder.

**OVERHEAD PIPING**—Shall be galvanized pipe, extending beyond end and toward front of washer. Shall provide connection between water inlet-connection on tub and valves mounted on vertical extension; pipe stand shall be furnished to support pipe.

Shall have cadmium plated steel apron. Hinged monel metal combination drain board and unloading apron attached to tub case of washer shall divert flow of water back into tub.

Wringer, wringer motor and drive shall be mounted on bracket at left hand side of machine. Assembly shall be mounted so that wringer may be swivelled from a position flat against the end of the machine to its operating position, and shall be locked in either position.

WRINGER MOTOR—Shall be gear-reduced, ball bearing, grease-lubricated, totally enclosed type with individual control for starting and stopping.

BELT DRIVE ONLY

DRIVE—Shall be through single reduction roller chain from automatic reverse header to cylinder sprocket.

AUTOMATIC REVERSE HEADER—Shall consist of three pulleys, two fixed and one loose, driven by flat belts from customer's line shaft.

An automatic worm and cam movement, moving belts alternately from the fast to loose pulleys, shall assure uniform number of cylinder revolutions between reversals with but slight difference in either direction of rotation.

Header shall be arranged so that belts may be shifted manually when required.

BRAKE—Shall be manually operated, contracting-band type, with two position lever, ON and OFF.

SPECIAL ITEMS

Furnished As Extras When Ordered

WATER-LEVEL GAGE GLASS—Shall be fitted into one end of tub and indicate height of liquid in cylinder.

DIAL TYPE WATER-LEVEL GAGE—Shall be hydrostatic-type indicator calibrated in inches, and located in position convenient for observation.

OVERHEAD PIPING—Shall be galvanized pipe, extending beyond end and toward front of washer. Shall provide connection between water inlet-connection on tub and valves mounted on vertical extension; pipe stand shall be furnished to support pipe.

BACK PIPING—Shall be galvanized pipe, extending beyond end of washer. Shall provide connection between water inlet-connection on tub and valves mounted on vertical extension; pipe stand shall be furnished to support pipe.

MANUAL TYPE WATER INLET VALVES—Shall be AMERICAN QUICK OPENING, GLOBE type. One valve shall be furnished for each of the hot and cold water lines.

Valves shall be so designed that they will close automatically when a predetermined amount of water has entered the machine.

WASHOMETER—Shall be designed to open outlet valve and ring bell at end of predetermined period. When specified, recording device shall be furnished consisting of stylus and tape to record washing cycle and outlet valve operation.

STEAM VALVE AND PIPING—Shall consist of brass steam piping connected to steam inlet in tub case and equipped with Globe type steam valve.

SUPPLY BOWL AND PIPING—Shall consist of bowl with flat sides mounted on same end of machine as steam inlet piping. Shall be connected to a steam siphon with check and control valves and shall be fitted with ¼-inch water pipe and globe valve for flushing the tank.

The Hoffman "Junior Silver Crest" Monel Washer shall be equipped with a monel metal cylinder 24 inches in diameter by inches long (inside measurements) and shall have doors vertical partitions providing compartments.

The washer shall be equipped with:

- Water piping
- Quick opening water valves
- Automatic water valves
- Steam piping

Shell—The shell sheets shall be constructed of .043" (19 gauge) monel metal. Flanged head liners shall be .050" (18 gauge) monel metal. On the lower half, the shell sheets and flanged head liners shall be welded into a leak-proof unit securely attached to inwardly projecting flanges on the cast iron frames.

The cast iron end frames shall support the cylinder and all driving mechanisms and shall be provided with leveling lugs. The feet shall be provided with bored holes for securely bolting machine to foundation. A seal shall be provided to prevent lubricants from entering the washing compartment and also to prevent the washing solution from coming in contact with the trunion bearings.

The shell shall be provided with upwardly sliding door of monel metal. Door shall slide in monel metal guides bolted to the shell heads.

Hinged monel metal apron to bridge the gap between cylinder and shell shall be provided.

Cylinder—Cylinder sheets shall be constructed of .043" (19 gauge) monel metal, and the flanged head sheets of .043" (19 gauge) monel metal shall be securely riveted to heavy cast iron transmitter.

Three 3½-inch lifting ribs of .043" (19 gauge) monel metal shall be provided extending the full length of the cylinder. Ribs shall be secured to the transmitter by monel metal outside rib stirrups and inside driving lugs riveted to the transmitters and the ribs.

Vertical partitions when specified shall be constructed of .043" (19 gauge) monel metal. Partitions shall be flanged and welded to the cylinder sheets. Partitions shall be secured to the ribs by monel metal rib stirrups riveted to the ribs and the partitions.

An upwardly sliding door of .043" (19 gauge) monel metal shall be provided for each compartment. Each door shall be equipped with two cast nickel alloy wedge type removable latches.

Doors shall latch in both the open and closed positions. Doors shall operate in slides constructed of monel metal. Slides shall be securely fastened to the cylinder and provide free movement of the doors.

Doors shall be provided with full length interlocking hook at top which shall act as a seal and prevent distortion. Bottom of door shall rest in a closely fitted recess extending its entire length.
All cylinder sheets, door sheets, and sides of ribs shall be perforated. Alternate rows of perforations shall be staggered.

Transmitters shall be of nickel cast iron with outwardly extending flanges. Transmitters shall be provided with one-piece malleable iron trunnion securely bolted.

Cylinder sheets and flanged head sheets shall be securely riveted to the transmitters.

Bearings—Trunnion bearings shall be unit type, flanged, and shall be fitted with Durex bearings, externally lubricated. Bearings shall be securely bolted to the cast iron end frames and the shell head.

Water Inlet—One water inlet shall be provided, at the center on the back of the shell, above the center line of the washer.

Outlet Valve—Washer shall be provided with a round, self-cleaning, self-sealing gasketless outlet valve. Valve shall be 4 inches in diameter to rapidly drain the shell. Valve shall be treadle operated and treadle shall be equipped with mechanism to hold the valve in the open position. Steam inlet shall be located in the outlet valve chamber.

Automatic Valves—Automatic valves, when specified, shall be located on the right end of the front of the washer at a convenient height.

Quick Opening Valves—When specified, separate quick opening valves for hot and cold water shall be located on the front of the washer at the right end at a convenient height.

Steam Piping—When specified, brass steam piping extending beyond the end of the washer shall be connected with the steam inlet on the outlet valve. Steam piping shall be fitted with a globe valve, the control for which shall be located on the right end at the front of the machine at a convenient height.

Drive—Cylinder shall be driven from right hand end by a combination worm gear reducer and machine cut spur gear drive. The motor shall be mounted on a rigid bracket cast integrally with the right hand end frame.

Gear Guards—The drive shall be fully enclosed in a cast iron guard.

Motor—Motor shall be of ample capacity to operate the washer continuously under full loads in accordance with standards of National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

Brake—The motor shall be provided with a solenoid operated brake of the spring set type, of sufficient capacity to stop and hold the cylinder against rotation upon interruption of the current.

Control Panel—The controller shall be of the contactor type, provided with a motor-driven timer, and thermal type overload relays. Timer shall insure that the number of revolutions in one direction will vary but slightly from those in the opposite direction.

Controller shall be furnished in a sheet metal cabinet with removable cover mounted on the washer. When specified, controller can be furnished for panel board mounting.

Control Station—Push button control station shall be mounted on the right hand end of shell providing "On," "Safe," and "Inching" features.

Interlocks—The sliding shell door shall be electrically interlocked so that the opening of the door will interrupt the motor current, set the brake and prevent further motion of the cylinder under power, except for inching.

Wiring—Washers furnished with machine mounted controller shall be provided with wiring in conduit. Wiring shall include connections to motor, push-button station, interlock switch, and controller. Provision shall be made at controller for service connections. Service disconnect switch shall be furnished by purchaser.

Washers furnished with remote mounted or panel board mounted controller shall be provided with wiring in conduit connecting push-button station and interlock switch. All wiring, including motor lead, shall terminate in a junction box located on the back of the washer. Unless otherwise specified, wiring from washer to controller and service disconnect switch shall be furnished by purchaser.

All wiring furnished and installed on the machine shall be in accordance with the National Electrical Code.

Lubrication—External means shall be provided for lubricating all bearings and gears.

The Blakeslee-Built Model C20 Mixer is regularly supplied in a floor model which is definitely preferred to a bench model since valuable counter space is saved and since heavy beaters are not built up without the weight and mechanical action of a Mixer. When desired, the Blakeslee-Built Model C20 Mixer is also available in a bench model for installation on an existing bench, or preferably for installation on a Blakeslee-Built steel painted or stainless steel cabinet stand especially designed and built for use with a Mixer which also provides space for storing beaters, whips and auxiliary attachments.

**Design and Construction**

Floor type with variable speed drive, planetary action and speeds developed between 110 RPM and 540 RPM, with planetary action and single lever control. Mixing speeds rapidly increased or decreased by means of a conveniently located hand wheel. No clutch to operate or gears to shift. Beaters and whips are continually in motion as speeds are changed, eliminating wash and start strain, as well as stopping of materials being mixed. Column constructed of 10 gauge steel all welded construction.

**Gear Box for Planetary Action**

First speed reduction by worm and gear, insuring quiet operation at all speeds. Ball bearings used where advisable with oil impregnated Oliver bronze bearings at other points.

Oil is drawn into the planetary gear box and takes its oil supply from the lowest point of the lower gear box. This point is below the oil seals at the beater shaft so that no oil can possibly leak out around the beater shaft. Oil is pumped up under pressures through the bearings and circulates in a continuous manner over the gears effectively providing an oil film between all moving parts, eliminating any need for hand lubrication with its attendant neglect. Gear box need only have its oil sump kept full of oil, the oil pump taking care of its circulation.

**Beater Lock and Bowl Raising Mechanism**

Beater lock designed and built so that all surfaces are open and easily cleaned; Bowl raised and lowered by conveniently located hand lever and is self locking in up or down position. Mixing bowl raised and lowered by lever and drag link located within the column preventing contamination from the mix which greatly simplifies cleaning.

**Motor and Switch**

13 HP General Electric, Westinghouse, Continuous equal, grease packed, ball bearing motor. Approval number which mounted on side of Mixer convenient to operator.

ISLAND ARRANGEMENT

TWO 2-OVEN RANGES - BACK TO BACK

The back-to-back island arrangement shown above has all the practicality and economy of the four-in-line plan, and is used generally for commercial installations where space is a factor to be considered, or for ships' galleys. Any pair of Malahat ranges, one-oven, two-oven, or three-oven, can be arranged on the back-to-back island plan. In determining your plan selection, check the measurements of the space available and the convenience you require in operation.

Because of the special Malahat design with internal flues and stack, ranges fit back-to-back snugly, and the overall width of any combination of back-to-back Malahat ranges will not exceed 66 inches.

Economy of fuel (particularly when oil is used) plus convenience of operation, was the reason for its adoption where the Armed Services' requirements demanded facility for 175 to 225 men at one sitting. The above arrangement of four oven and two burners is most convenient, economical, and is highly recommended for commercial practice in hotels, camps and institutions. It is true that when oil is used a one-burner, three-oven range would ordinarily accommodate up to 150 men, but that would mean one burner in constant use with no margin of facility in the event of breakdown.

On the other hand, the above arrangement, with faithfully Kresky Pattern Oil Burners in the boxes, assures no waste of oil fuel through necessity of three ovens during long periods when only two ovens in use are all that are required. Between rush periods, one range is shut down completely, the other being in use for short orders—a definite and practical economy—and at the same time giving a standby in case of break-down.

Note in the illustration that the interchangeable stove outlets allow standard left hand fireboxes at either side of the island and the two stacks together for a single smoke pipe (by means of a Y piece). Fireboxes can also be left and right, opposite each other if so desired.

"The chimney builder got through at Anaham last week and I say him the same day. He came here yesterday and had a look at our chimneys. The one here in the Fathers house is too small for the furnace and there is a crack through it on the second floor. The chimney itself stands right next to the wood of the walls and floors so that it is a serious fire hazard. The only remedy is to build a new chimney. The other chimney which I had Mr. Mikkelsen look at is the one in the kitchen which I already spoke to you about. This chimney is broken in a number of places for about 15 feet from the base up and including the base. The base of this chimney stands in the middle of the vegetable room where a good part of the kitchen work is done. Since the chimney-sweep pointed out to me the danger of this chimney last summer I feared it might collapse and cause some serious accident. Mr. Mikkelsen says there is danger of the chimney crumbling at the bottom and damaging the roof and floors. It is also a very serious fire hazard. There is another chimney in the kitchen to which the kitchen range and a furnace in the basement are attached. Mr. Mikkelsen said that this chimney too would have to be taken down and another one built, because it was badly built and would not be accepted by a fire inspector. He said that if he worked on one chimney and left the others stand he could lose his permit, or if anything happened later on he could be held responsible for not having reported the danger to the fire inspector. About that second chimney in the kitchen there was never any complaint, but the cooks always complained about the wood, if it is not tinder dry the meals are delayed or they come out half cooked, the chimney might have something to do with this. It will cost about $600.00 to rebuild these chimneys, that is a very rough estimate. Mr. Mikkelsen thinks that it would be better if he came back with the fire inspector and on his report I could apply to the Department for some help towards this expense, and he asked me if I could give him an answer in about 3 days time."

Re: Caribou Residential School

With reference to Mr. Neary's letters of November 23rd and June 8th, 1946, in connection with a proposal for replacement of the buildings at the above-mentioned school and in particular the construction of a heating plant in a separate unit, which would handle the present school and which would form the first part of the new residential school, Father Morris called at this office recently and the matter was discussed at some length. I gathered that the proposal was not clearly understood by Father Morris in the first instance, he having in mind that the heating unit would be designed primarily to meet the requirements of the existing school. I informed him that this was not so and the Department had in mind the replacement of the residential school unit by unit, over a period of years, which proposal, reference his letter of December 16th, attached, is apparently satisfactory to him.

It is presumed that plans and specifications for the new buildings will be completed before consideration is given to the type and size of heating unit required, to insure that the unit, when installed, will adequately meet the requirements of the new buildings. In my letter of August 17th I agreed that the heating plant should be the first unit of the new school establishment to be erected and recommended that the Lands and Development Services Branch be approached with a view to having the necessary plans and specifications prepared. It is somewhat late in the year to proceed with this now, unless the primary work has been completed by the
Engineering Branch, but if the funds available for the Caribou School this year can be spent to advantage erecting the heating unit, I would ask that such action as may be necessary be taken immediately, or otherwise that the Department purchase the equipment referred to in my letter of October 15th this year and that an early start be made next year on the heating unit.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Re: Caribou Indian Residential School,
Williams Lake Agency, B.C.

With reference to Major Mackay's memorandum of February 24th bearing your marginal notation of the 26th ultimo in connection with the above, you are advised as follows:

The proposal to erect a central heating plant housed in a separate building to serve the existing residential school at present and to serve the future new residential school groups, is sound from an engineering point of view.

In order to arrange to heat the existing building from this plant, it will be necessary to know the type of heating system and the load requirements of the building. This will necessitate a thorough inspection by a qualified heating engineer.

The full extent of the proposed new development must be known in order to design a heating plant having sufficient capacity. If it is intended to delay the erection of the group of buildings comprising the new residential school, it would be advantageous and economical to restrict the central heating plant to one boiler at the start. The boiler room should be made sufficiently large to provide space for a complete plant even if only part of the equipment is to be installed at the start.

Since the proposed new residential school is to be comprised of several blocks, the central steam plant should be designed for high pressure. Distribution to the various buildings could be made overhead through covered passages connecting the building and power plant; with steam lines to each individual building fitted with two stages of pressure reducing valves. With two stages of pressure reduction, the plant could be operated at medium pressures at such times that the laundry service etc., were not being used, and also in the spring and fall.

It goes without saying that such a plant would require qualified operating staff for the boiler room.

It is felt that the inspection of the existing residential school by our heating engineer will have to be deferred until some of the priority jobs in the office requiring his attention, have been cleared. We will endeavour to fit this inspection in with several other calls in the west as soon as our program of work will permit.

Dear Bernard:

Re: Cariboo Residential School

Your personal letter of March 10th re the above has been given a great deal of thought, not only by myself and Mr. Christie, our Williams Lake Superintendent, but by the School Principal and The Reverend Father O'Grady as well.

On my return from the East, I had a meeting as to the best method of utilizing the available and non-transferable funds prior to the end of the fiscal year and when it was found that we could not secure heating equipment, inquiries were made re the purchase of dimensional lumber, gravel, cement etc.

It was our considered opinion that to store a large quantity of cement would be too hazardous and might possibly involve considerable loss with resultant criticism from outside. There still remains considerable dispute as to where we can secure quantities of suitable gravel and it appears that by a brief delay in making purchase we might avoid a long haul. The purchase of lumber also proved extremely difficult.

In view of the above we regret to have missed the opportunity of making purchases at this time, which would have utilized the available funds, rather than have them revert to Consolidated Account at the close of the fiscal year. Re: Cariboo Indian Residential School

I left Kamloops by car at 4:30 p.m. on the 28th instant accompanied by Father Morris who is the Principal at the above. We arrived at Cariboo School after a motor trip up the Cariboo Trail lasting seven hours.

Upon looking over the set up here today I feel impelled to submit a preliminary report as conditions are totally different from the description outlined by officials at the Indian Affairs Branch.

The Class room block, Laundry, Kitchen, Fathers House and Boys Dormitory are separate buildings and in addition to these there are the usual farm buildings and implement sheds including a Residence for the farm staff. There is also a Church on the property.

The buildings are spaced a considerable distance apart as will be seen from a rough Plot Plan which was prepared some time ago and which I am bringing back with me.

All of the buildings were erected before 1900 and some of them date back to 1890 and 1870. Summed up in a few words it can be stated that the buildings are in a terrible state of dilapidation and while the staff are continually working to keep them clean, the task is well nigh impossible.

The buildings are all heated by decrepit and totally inefficient bricked up gravity warm air furnaces. These units are in such condition that they are useless and when the weather gets severe the staff is kept busy thawing frozen water pipes and all activity in the Class rooms is halted as the temperature drops to the thirtys inside. This is not to be doubted as the layout, such as it is, could not be worsened.

No point would be gained in building the proposed new Heating Plant before the proposed new School is erected as it would be very impractical to attempt to connect to the existing buildings. Great expense and much labour would be involved, all of which would be lost when the new School goes into operation.

The object in writing this preliminary report is to bring to the attention of the Indian Affairs Branch the most urgent necessity of providing as soon as is humanly possible, heating equipment designed to give some degree of relief from the present primitive and useless junk.

After duly considering all phases of the set up and having in mind the intention to build a new school, and not overlooking the economic angle, it is recommended that pipeless furnaces be obtained in the numbers required for the buildings to bring about improvements in the heating which are vitally needed if the health of the pupils and staff is to be safeguarded.

Before leaving here I will obtain the necessary data from which suitable furnaces may be selected, as well as data relative to the location of the heating plant and the school.

I expect to leave for Lejac tomorrow.

C.H. Buck, M.R.A.I.C.,
Chief Architect,
Engineering & Construction Division,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

(Sgd) A.H. Hargreaves.

The Class room block, Laundry, Kitchen, Father's House and Boys Dormitory are separate buildings and in addition to these there are the usual farm buildings and implement sheds including a Residence for the farm staff. There is also a Church on the property.

The buildings are spaced a considerable distance apart as will be seen from a rough Plot Plan which was prepared some time ago and which I am bringing back with me.

All of the buildings were erected before 1900 and some of them date back to 1890 and 1870. Summed up in a few words it can be stated that the buildings are in a terrible state of dilapidation and while the staff are continually working to keep them clean, the task is well nigh impossible.

The buildings are all heated by decrepit and totally inefficient bricked up gravity warm air furnaces. These units are in such condition that they are useless and when the weather gets severe the staff is kept busy thawing frozen water pipes and all activity in the Class rooms is halted as the temperature drops to the thirtys inside. This is not to be doubted as the layout, such as it is, could not be worsened.

No point would be gained in building the proposed new Heating Plant before the proposed new School is erected as it would be very impractical to attempt to connect to the existing buildings. Great expense and much labour would be involved, all of which would be lost when the new School goes into operation.

The object in writing this preliminary report is to bring to the attention of the Indian Affairs Branch the most urgent necessity of providing as soon as is humanly possible, heating equipment designed to give some degree of relief from the present primitive and useless junk.

After duly considering all phases of the set up and having in mind the intention to build a new school, and not overlooking the economic angle, it is recommended that pipeless furnaces be obtained in the numbers required for the buildings to bring about improvements in the heating which are vitally needed if the health of the pupils and staff is to be safe-guarded.

Before leaving here I will obtain the necessary data from which suitable furnaces may be selected, as well as data relative to the location of the heating plant and the school.

I expect to leave for Lejac tomorrow.

C.H. Buck, M.R.A.I.C.,
Chief Architect,
Engineering & Construction Division,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

(Sgd) A.H. Hargreaves.

June 22, 1949.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

On May 30th I was very pleased to receive Mr. Hargreaves of the Dep't of Mines & Resources, who had come to inspect the buildings and especially the heating system of the school here.

I do not know if Mr. Hargreaves has yet made a report on the school or if his report has reached you, but I do believe that he was somewhat disappointed in the conditions he found here. He did not expect to find the heating system so inadequate and obsolete, or the buildings so old and scattered. His report, I am sure, will give you a good picture of the situation.

For three years we have been hoping that something would be done to give us a better heating system and remove at least to some extent the terrible fire hazard we have to contend with at present. I am sure that Mr. Hargreaves' report will be the beginning of some solution to these conditions.

The ideal of a central steam heating plant does not seem practicable for these old buildings, because of the distance the buildings are apart and the lack of any previous steam system.

Mr. Hargreaves mentioned the possibility of pipeless furnaces as a temporary measure. I am sure that these furnaces would give us some much needed heat, and would be a big improvement over the present furnaces, some of which are very old. One at least needs immediate replacement: the furnace in the kitchen building which is completely burnt out.

While these pipeless hot air furnaces would be an improvement, they would still not be an entirely adequate heating system. Moreover, it would require five or six separate furnaces to heat the classrooms and girls' building, and an extra furnace in each of the other buildings. That would leave the fire hazard as much a problem as ever.

The buildings are very old. The main building has been in use since 1880, and the building which houses the boys was put up in 1895. Years have deteriorated the buildings so that they are cold, not only from the lack of a proper heating system, but also because they are no longer fit for the rigors of these winters.

I would say a new school is our immediate need and the answer to the many
problems we have been facing these past years. So I beg of you, in the interest of these children, to do everything possible that would hasten the construction of new school buildings.

Yours very truly,

J.A. Morris O.M.I.
