Memorandum

Re: Cariboo Indian Residential School,
Williams Lake, B.C.

Further to our field report dated May 30th with reference to the above you are advised as follows.

A meeting was held in Major MacKay's office on June 30th with Major MacKay, Col. Neary, Father Birch O.M.I., Mr. Buck and Mr. Hargreaves in attendance, for the purpose of considering the best means of dealing with the conditions at the above.

For the record, it was tentatively decided to adapt the Wabasca Dormitory Building plans for this site with the minimum of changes to the drawings.

This memorandum is intended to deal only with the drastic requirements in connection with the existing heating systems. It was pointed out at the meeting, that in the Classroom Building and Girls' Dormitory temperatures drop to about 34 and 36 degrees in extremely cold weather. The Laundry Building, Kitchen Dining Room Block, Fathers' House and Boys' Dormitory Building also were exceptionally cold and under severe weather conditions all activity in these buildings ceased.

Repeating what was said in our field memorandum, the existing warm air heating plants serving these buildings are all in a hopeless state, and it is a certainty that there is no possibility of bringing about satisfactory repairs.

It was suggested at the meeting that a number of new warm air pipeless furnaces be installed in these buildings to provide means of temporary relief from the cold as well as to decrease the fire hazard. When the new Dormitory Building is erected together with a new Classroom Block, it is the intention to raze the existing buildings at which time these new pipeless furnaces may be removed and set aside for use elsewhere.

We were requested to prepare an outline specification and plan covering the temporary heating requirements and the Indian Affairs Branch agreed to request the Departmental Purchasing Agent to order the necessary equipment upon receipt of our information.

When our officer was at this school he outlined the location of the proposed pipeless furnaces to the Principal. In addition to that a rough plot plan was obtained from which a sketch drawing has been prepared showing approximate locations of the heating units.

With reference to your circular letter of May 23, 1949 regarding an amount of $12,800.00 available for alterations to the heating system and equipment for Cariboo Indian Residential School I am forwarding a requisition submitted by Rev. J. A. Morris, O.M.I., Principal.

Regarding the heating system, Mr. Hargreaves, heating engineer, recently inspected the heating system in this school. From what I could gather he had been asked to investigate the possibilities of a central heating system for this school which could be adapted to supply heat for a new building, but meanwhile supplying the present buildings.

Mr. Hargreaves found this would be impossible, and I believe he is recommending that pipeless furnaces be installed in the old building before winter in view of the deplorable condition of the present heating arrangements.

These furnaces could be salvaged and sold if a new building is erected.

The other equipment listed is urgently required and can be utilized in the new school.

Regarding an additional electric lighting plant. The school has had considerable trouble with the present one, which is an 18 K.W. Shepherd Diesel.

While I am of the opinion that an institution of this kind should have two power units so that there is an opportunity to do an overhaul and that when a repair is required for one unit the other can be expected to carry on, it is too bad that when the present unit was purchased consideration was not given to the purchase of two 9 K.W. units, rather than one 18 K.W.

There is also the possibility that the B. C. Power Commission, which supplies light and power to the village of Williams Lake, may be persuaded to extend their lines to the 150 Mile House and the
Cariboo Residential School within the next year or two. This would eliminate one service which seems to give considerable trouble from time to time.

Rev. Morris left for Ottawa last Sunday, and I suggested that he should take these matters up with head office.

MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, July 27, 1949.

Re: Cariboo Indian Residential School.

This school has been badly neglected, and has deteriorated so badly it is now an actual fire trap. It is located near Williams Lake, B.C., an area where very low temperatures prevail in winter. The existing conditions were not completely brought to light until Mr. Har- greaves carried out his last inspection trip, by which time it was too late to initiate a major building replacement programme this year.

Some relief to pupils and staff in safe dormitory accommoda- dation, that can be properly heated, is required immediately. To this end, this office has recommended the replacement of quite a number of existing worn out furnaces, by the installation of pipeless furnaces, as a temporary measure until the existing buildings can be replaced.

The intention of the Indian Affairs Branch is to proceed as soon as possible with the erection of one of our typical four class-room school buildings, which eventually will serve its academic pur- pose but which immediately upon completion will be assigned to the pupils and teaching sisters as dormitory accommodation.

The sum of $40,000.00 has been included in the 1949-50 es- timates for the building which it is felt should be increased to $50,000.00.

The adaption measures required are to design an attached fireproof annex wherein will be located the heating plant, and power producing equipment, for immediate use, and to design a heating system of the proportions required which can later be hooked up with the eventual boiler plant serving a new main building containing the usual fea- tures of a residential school.

Your Chief Architect has attended meetings with the Director of Indian Affairs, his Superintendent of Education and the church au- thorities interested, and has consented to undertake the operations involved, provided that it was agreeable to Indian Affairs that such work was not to interrupt the heavy programme now under way.

It now appears that Departmental agreement to this arrange- ment has not been obtained.

Since all members of our architectural staff are engaged on work already assigned top priority, it has not been possible to give the Cariboo school project any attention since receiving the memorandum of July 15th from the Acting Director of Indian Affairs.

If better results are to be achieved, it will be necessary to retain the services of an architect in private practice and instruct him on our requirements.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

The Director, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

I have received a copy of your correspondence relating to the Cariboo Indian Residential School addressed to Mr. W. S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner for B. C.

After receiving this letter I immediately visited the Cariboo School, and with the acting Principal Father Fleury, went over the buildings to see if we could obtain the number of pipeless furnaces that we could dispense with, in view of the new school block, which is to be used temporarily as a dormitory.

The following is quoted from our night letter of July 25 regarding these pipeless furnaces:

"Re Cariboo Indian Residential School and your letter of July 21 to Mr. Arneil. Father Morris has not returned but Father Fleury and I consider six Class A and six Class B pipeless furnaces still necessary in old buildings with new classroom block."

I would like to explain why more of these pipeless furnaces cannot be eliminated, by going over each building separately:

1. Convent and school:
   The girls' dormitories are situated on the end wings on the second floor. Immediately below them on the first floor are the four classrooms.

   In the centre wing downstairs is the girls' recreation and sewing room, with the chapel upstairs.

   The remainder of the main building downstairs is a reception room, and upstairs the Sisters' sleeping and living quarters.

   It is very doubtful if the four-room classroom block can provide dormitory space for one hundred and twenty-five boys and girls, and also the female staff or Sisters, and we still have to provide heat for the four classrooms, sewing room, and chapel. However, we have decided that one pipeless furnace, Class B, can be dispensed with in this building.
2. Boys' Building:

According to Father Fleury the present furnace in the boys' building is fairly satisfactory, except during occasional cold spells in the winter. The first floor of this building is used as the boys' recreation room.

With sleeping accommodation for the boys being provided in the new classroom block I would think that the present furnace would be quite satisfactory to heat the recreation room. However, Father Fleury seemed to think that it would be difficult to provide sleeping accommodation for all the children in the new building, and suggested that only one pipeless Class A furnace should be installed in this building, instead of three as proposed by Mr. Hargreaves.

3, 4 & 5. Laundry, Kitchen, & Dining Room, Fathers' House:

It was decided that these buildings require the number of pipeless furnaces suggested by Mr. Hargreaves.

Labour:

Mr. R. Kelt, local tinsmith, was contacted regarding installation of pipeless furnaces, and gave me an estimate for labour alone of $60.00 per furnace.

Mr. Pete Vogelaar, local contractor, submitted a price of $2.00 per foot for brick chimneys. He further advised that the standard size of flue lining for chimneys here is 12 x 12, or 8 x 12.

Electricity:

The local manager of the B.C. Power Commission was contacted regarding the supply of electricity, and is making a survey of the power requirements in the territory between the end of the line and the Cariboo Indian Residential School, which he will submit to his head office.

I might add that in 1946 some of our local members promised to extend the line to the 150 Mile House and the Cariboo School, and I believe that there would be sufficient power required to justify extension of the present system.

encl. Wm. Christie, Supt., Williams Lake Indian Agency.

c.c. Mr. Arneil

In reply to your memorandum of November 9th regarding purchase order 47895 for twelve pipeless furnaces for the Cariboo Indian Residential School, I have to advise that these furnaces have not yet been received.

Mr. Perry of the Kumfort Furnace Company Limited called at this office and also at the Cariboo Indian Residential School on Saturday with a view to advising us regarding installation. He further advised that there is some hold-up on account of scarcity of galvanized iron to complete the furnaces. I might add that Mr. Perry informed us that these furnaces only have a firebox which takes sixteen inch wood. It was presumed that in view of the fact that they were wood burning furnaces that they would accommodate at least two foot wood. Father Morris is rather disturbed as it will cost more money to cut sixteen inch wood and in view of the fact that he already has a supply of two foot wood.

Presumably it is too late to do much about it at this date but Father Morris is contacting Mr. Arneil by telephone today.

"On Saturday there was a man here from the Comfort Furnace Co., the firm which will supply the furnaces purchased by the Dept. for our school here. He said that the furnaces ordered would be of two sizes: one size to burn wood 16 inches long, the other to burn wood 20 inches long, or both could burn coal. Now that's a smaller fire box than our kitchen range which is 28 inches. Coal is expensive here, about $19.50 per ton and wood cut down to 16" and 20" is just as bad, not only in the labour of cutting all the wood that small but also in trying to keep 12 or 15 such little fires going. Even the men from the Comfort Furnace Co. thought it was a queer idea. He said they had a somewhat similar furnace which was designed for wood and took a 46 inch stick and he thought that would be a more suitable size. We use 46 inch wood in our present furnaces and they are more than enough work as it is. I made it clear to the Dept. that we could not get coal at present. I have been trying to get the Commissioner on the phone today but could not so I'll drop him a line. But I think that little can be done at this end. This plan was to be for one season only, but since they are not going to build the school next year, it looks as though we will be stuck with these little furnaces for a long time..........."

Dear Mother:

You will be surprised when you open this letter and find it comes from a poor little missionary Sister, but I feel confident that if I appeal to you in our need you will do something for us. Our country has been without a mother long enough and during that time too many little ones, especially "little Indians" have suffered. Only a mother's heart understands what it is to be at the head of a family, unable to give them the comfort she would like them to enjoy. This is really my greatest worry here at St. Joseph's Mission (Cariboo Indian School). I first came here in 1929 as a young Sister, two years later was sent to another mission, then was transferred here again in 1933 and have been stationed here ever since. All those years, the Indian Department has given us hopes of a new school, so much so that since ten years no repairs have been done to our buildings because they were condemned and not worth repairing. Imagine dear Mother, (permit me to call you by that name, it makes me feel more at ease to tell you all I wish to relate, after all, you really are our Mother) in what state they are in now, so cold and dilapidated. Our Principal is a very kind person and does all he can to improve the situation but he has not the means to buy the necessary things. We have no conveniences at all in our buildings. The only electric machines we have are a potato peeler and a churn. No bread cutter, food chopper or mixers of any kind. Not even a cooling unit for the summer months! In winter we do not need any, the house is cold enough, ha! ha! Our Principal has asked the Indian Department several times for a washing machine too, also a fridgidaire, an electric food mixer, and a dryer for the laundry but so far, we have not received anything. Very often we have "blackouts" not because we have war here, but the plant that was given two years ago was a second hand one and is always out of order.
Our Mother Provincial is terribly afraid that our Convent will go up in flames some fine night and has asked my opinion about closing the school until a new one is built. But I hate to think of that idea because our Indian children are improving in every way and many of them have practically nothing at home. In spite of our miseries they are happy and have a very good spirit.

Now, Mother, I have come to my big request; May I ask you please to have a good talk with Mr. St. Laurent (I am sure he does not know in what state this place is; Mr. Hargraves the engineer who came here last June would tell him the truth in regards to buildings, etc.) and ask him to plead for us, so that we could have a new school for next fall? The Sisters and children would always claim you as their greatest Benefactress and would pray daily for you, Mrs. St. Laurent.

I know they are making plans and promise a new building soon, but they are so slow, and besides, Fr. Principal was called to Ottawa last July and after much debating with the Head officials, he understood that they did not intend building a very large school in fact, he thinks we will not have as much space as we have now, and our old buildings are already too small. We have to refuse admittance to some because we are crowded. There are seventy five girls and fifty three boys in all. I know it takes money for such a school, but on the other hand, I feel sorry to see so many little souls suffering. They have built such schools before. Do you think I am asking too much, Mother? I am asking the Poor Souls in Purgatory to help us to obtain this long sought for favor; and I also pray for you and your dear one, that God may bless all your undertakings,

I remain,
Yours in the Sacred Heart of Jesus,

Sister John Baptist.

VICTORIA, B.C., April 15, 1929.

Dear Sir:

I have the honour herewith to submit Voucher No.5-A for $95.83 in favour of E.H.Shockley, 230 Central Street, Vancouver, B.C. for wood work material purchased by Rev.Father Rohr, Principal of the Cariboo Indian Residential School, for use in the manual training class at that School.

It is regretted that this Voucher could not have been forwarded before the close of the fiscal year, but the delay was due to the fact that there is no mill near the Cariboo School from which these supplies could be purchased. Father Rohr came to Victoria and consulted me and I advised him to buy the supplies in Vancouver from the firm who supplied the material for the work benches. This he did, but he has only now received the same.

Authority for the above mentioned purchase is contained in a letter from the Deputy Superintendent General dated February 6, 1929, File 600224.

Your obedient servant,

W.E.Ditchburn.
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Enclosures:

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, May 15, 1929.

Reverend Sir:

The Department is making special efforts to improve the instruction in manual and vocational training for boys in the Indian schools of British Columbia. If this phase of our educational program can be made more effective, it will greatly benefit the Indians of the Province. Most residential schools lack a workshop or other space that can be used for vocational training. If steps to improve the workshop facilities should be taken at the Cariboo Indian Residential School, please cooperate with Mr. Indian Agent Taylor with a view to making a recommendation to the Department.

A thorough course in carpentry is the present aim. To this end, Mr. Commissioner Duthieburn has been authorized to supply benches and tools and there has been directed to you a text on manual training, job sheets in woodworking and a publication on how to work with tools and wood. Further, you have been authorized to present to Mr. Agent Taylor reasonable accounts for materials with which to work.

The Department is desirous of having a qualified instructor for this work at all schools where this special training is being undertaken. Some schools have on the staff an officer who is well qualified for the activity and who can be released from other duties for the manual training classes. I understand there are summer courses for instructors in manual training in Vancouver and Victoria. Other Indian schools are so situated that they can secure the services of instructors from municipal schools. In this case, classes are held two or three times per week. The Department would like to know what arrangements you have made, or can make, for this important work. Do not hesitate to enlist the cooperation of Mr. Taylor, if the Department can be of any assistance.

At a later date, it is hoped to extend the vocational training to include gas engines and other machinery; and, whenever you believe this additional course should be given at the Cariboo Indian Residential School, you will please inform the Department. A copy of this letter is being directed to Mr. Taylor for his information.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. V. Rohr, O. M. I.,
Principal,
Cariboo Indian Residential School,
150 Mile House, B. C.

Your obedient servant,

Sir;-

I have the honour to inform you that I am in receipt of a request from the Principal of the Cariboo Indian Residential School, for a blackboard 4'x 6' for use in the manual training shop.

Unless such supplies are sent out from the east by the Department, I would suggest that this be purchased from E.C. Farwell of Vancouver, B.C., who supplied the last shipment of desks for the school. Mr. Farwell sent me some time ago, a sample of "Slatoplate" blackboard which is guaranteed for ten years and is supplied in any lengths of four foot width.

I have no price for this particular board but a small piece such as requested should cost but little.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Dear Sir,

Last year in March I went to Victoria to call on Mr. W. E. Witchburn in connection with the manual training school which was to be established in every Indian Residential School. Mr. Witchburn was very kind and allowed us $500 = a year for the manual trainer. I engaged him at $60 = a month and board and he took charge of the manual training from April 1st 1929.

On May I left for a trip to the old Country and the school was left in the able hands of Rev. Mr. Patterson O.M.T. During my absence no bill was sent to the Department and on my return, Mr. Farrier promised me...

interest of $500 = a year for the manual train.

On January 1st, 1930 the whole amount for arrear wages due to the manual trainer was $450 = from April 27th January at $50 = a month.

Dear Sir:

Re: Technical Training

I beg to inform you that while in New Westminster last month I met the Rev. Father Rohr, Principal of the Cariboo Indian Residential School, at Williams Lake, and he informed me of the necessity for constructing a new workshop in which manual training work can be carried on and asked if the Department would supply the necessary material for this building. All the labor in connection with the construction would be performed by the pupils and the Manual Training Instructor. I said I thought the Department would do this and asked him to send me a bill of material.

Recently a bill of material was received through the Indian Agent at Williams Lake, but on scrutinizing the same I found this would run close on to $1,000.00 and, therefore, returned the same to Rev. Father Rohr asking him to modify his demands. I am now in receipt of an amended bill of material and I find from the local mills that the lumber itself will cost $46.00 nett f.o.b. mill Victoria, and the hardware, vitrified piping, etc., a further $200.00, making a total of $546.00. Freight, of course, to Williams Lake will be extra.

As there is a class of twelve pupils taking the manual training course at the Williams Lake School, the proposed new workshop is to be 24 x 52' overall and I would recommend that authority be given me to purchase this material, the same to be charged against the Technical Education allotment of the Special Grant out of this year's vote if possible.

I would be pleased to have your concurrence in this matter at an early date.

Yours obedient servant,

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR G. H. BARRY,
DATED JUNE 16, 1931, ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE
CARIBOO INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

MANUAL TRAINING:

Brother LaJoie is at present in charge of the manual training shop. Brother LaJoie does not hold a certificate in manual training. The manual training shop is about 50' x 24'. It is a nearly new building. There are 12 double benches. At present there are 12 boys taking the course. I do not consider the course being followed is one that could be classified as true manual training; it is a course in carpentry. The Principal hopes to get a trained teacher for manual training in the near future.

The boys have made chairs, seats, sleighs, towel racks, toilet cabinets, small stands, etc. They are now working on a model house of a fairly large size, about 5 or 6 feet by 4 feet. Only the floor and studding had been completed when I saw the work. The boys have done many repairs to farm machinery. Most of this has been done very well indeed.

The Principal reports that when he assumed the duties of that office, a number of the tools were missing.

The Principal is about to enclose part of the machine shed to make a shop where the boys can be taught the mechanics of engines and various farm machines, tractors, etc.

All the above training with the boys and girls helps them to become efficient upon graduation. The boys from this school will become for the most part either farmers, ranchers, or cowboys. I consider the training given in this school of the greatest possible help in later life. The conditions in the Cariboo and Chilcotin are very different from those in other parts of British Columbia.

I should like to see a trained and certificated teacher employed as a manual training instructor.

Dear Sir:

I beg to inform you that I am in receipt of a request from the Principal of the Cariboo Indian Residential School for the necessary lumber to build benches for use in the girl's sewing room. At present the smaller girls are compelled to sit upon the floor, or else stand, whilst sewing. The older girls use benches which were formerly used in the chapel, and they are very old and rickety and have to be supported by blocks of wood.

As the sewing room is also the girls play room, the benches are moved about a great deal, and therefore require to be of solid construction. With this in view the Principal has submitted to me a plan of a good solid bench, which can be built by the boys in the manual training class, thus combining useful instruction with utility.

The following quantities of Dressed Fir, are sufficient to construct ten benches. This lumber cannot be obtained locally, and would have to be shipped in. I believe the approximate cost, including freight would not exceed $40.00. This would give the School ten serviceable work benches, each 8'6" in length, for a cost of probably less than $4.00 each.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated March 19th (#1-1-11). Our mail service has prevented an earlier reply.

You will be gratified to learn that, with two exceptions, the ideas suggested in this letter have been anticipated in this School. Local circumstances have prevented us from training the girls in milking and gardening. We may, however, be able to change this.

The girls do all the washing by hand. They also, in turn, can make and bake all the bread used. They also, occasionally, make butter under the direction of a well-qualified instructor.
The boys do the milking and get practical instructions about the care of cows &c. They are taught to butcher and, the other day, I had them butcher three pigs while their instructor was away. A butcher comes here occasionally and gives them practical lessons—They are shown how to brand, dehorn & castrate and also to do other things they will have to do on their reserves. They do the gardening, the irrigating etc., and help in setting the hay, harvesting wheat etc. Those who show an aptitude for machinery are beginning to learn to handle a tractor, an envelope-cutter etc.—Our carpenter gives practical instruction in his art. Besides making chairs, tables, cabinets etc., they have, under his direction, put up a building. If the Department will supply the material, I will have them do more building (when necessary) as I consider this of more practical use than the making of chairs etc. I will take this up with the Indian Agent.

I trust that these few facts will show that our ideas run and how run along the same line as those of the Department.

I remain sincerely yours,

G. J. [Signature]

Kamloops, B.C., Sept. 15th, 1930.

Dear Sir:

I beg to make the following report upon my last visit to the Williams Lake No. 5 Agency.

School

St Joseph's Residential school was visited in company with the Agent and the Principal, the Rev. Father Rhor. I went over the school and there were 101 children in the school the day I visited the same. I examined some of the children in the class rooms. They appeared well up to standard in their work. The new carpenter shop for manual training was in course of erection by the boys of the school, and they were making a good job of it. As at all other schools the manual training is a great success. The Rev. Principal suggested an annual prize of a tool chest.

Extension of same to other trades, such as iron work and shoe and harness repairing is desirable. There has been little sickness in the school. The food is good, and was sufficient on the day of my visit. They were having for the next meal; stew, potatoes, bread, lettuce milk. All fire extinguishers were up and the children can be got out of the building in one and a half minutes, according to Mr. Taylor. The water supply is being rectified, as you know, and by this time work on this scheme has probably started. The fire extinguishers were in place, and are shortly to be refilled.

Geo. S. Pragnell.

Dear Sir:

In compliance with the request you made in your letter #160-0-II, dated Feb. 28th, 1934, I beg to submit the following report.

I. Vocational training for boys:

A/Carpentry. The instructor is W.H. Higgins, formerly of Betchen & Higgins, Vancouver, B.C., who is 58 years old. He has had over 30 years experience as a cabinet maker and as a building contractor. He has put up several houses and other buildings, as a contractor, and has made cabinets and other fixtures for banks, stores, offices, etc.

He reports that the following work has been done: Drafting, scale drawings by elevations, plans and sections; reading of plans made to different scales; building construction; farm work; making of gates, fences, feed racks, grain troughs, flumes. Under his direction, the boys took the levels for the flumes, ditches, skating-rink, etc.

Shop work: The heavier work consisted in making laundry tubs, panel and other doors, door frames, windows (including the putting in of the panes), kitchen and dining-room tables, cupboards, chairs and stools. Besides this there was the general repair work such as removing the foundations of part of the buildings and re-nailing dressing, sidewalks, etc. Part of the drains and of the foundations was cement work. A fire-escape, with a porch, was also built.

Lighter work: Wood turning, including rungs for chairs, handles for axes, hammers, sledges, chisels, etc.; cabinet work on chests, a gramophone record cabinet with carved figures of local animals, cowboys, etc. (This was made as Christmas present for the local Indian Agent). There were also kitchen utensils (especially for the ex-pupils, girls, who got married during the year), sleighs, and small jobs to teach the beginners to make joints, mitre, lap, dovetail, lock, dovetail and glue. We used our practically home-built circular saw to make grooves, rebats, mouldings, etc.

All this work is done to scaled drawings. I think that, as the boys will later be engaged in farms, the work they do is practical.

There are about nine boys in the class with a few more or less at times. All get about fifteen hours a week as a minimum but, when a boy is on a job, he spends two hours a day at it. During the winter months those who show most aptitude, about four at a time, thus get from 10 to 12 hours a week.

B/Blacksmithing. We have no regular course. However, occasionally, the manager of a neighbouring ranch, who was formerly a blacksmith, gives instruction to from four to six of the older boys. They have made gate hinges, braces and other iron parts, exclusive of the wheel, for wheelbarrows, etc., and ordinary wrenches from old files, etc. They made and put runners on about thirty dozen sleighs. Besides this, under the direction of this man's son, who has about 15 years of experience, they help out in the blacksmith shop when anything is being made or repaired, provided that this work is done during the time allotted to manual training or to work, i.e., from two to two and a half hours daily.

C/Farming and ranching. This work is done under the direction of the foreman or his assistant both of whom are about 35 years old and were brought up on farms. As the boys will have to do this work when they leave school, all do some of it after they are about fourteen. If the boys request it or if a boy, after a trial, is found to have no aptitude for carpentry, he spends a good deal of his work-time at this. That would be about ten hours daily and about four on Mondays when the girls are in the laundry. If there is a rush on, for example to dip the grain or potatoes before seeding, a day is taken for this. The same is true for picking the potatoes. We do not think that these exceptions average much over a day a month.

The work done: preparing seed and potatoes for planting; irrigating (including the cleaning of the irrigation ditches once a year); the upkeep of the ditches and fences—see "carpentry" above, etc.
irrigating done by the boys is done for the garden and potato field. An irrigator is employed for the hay. In the afternoons he sometimes takes a boy with him during the work period. The boys, under his direction or that of the Foreman or Manual Trainer work at some of the ditches used for the hay. The hay is put up and the grain cut by the men. Any boys who stay here during the holidays help stock and thresh. It is the custom that those about to be discharged spend their last few days in the camp or the parents sometimes ask to have their children spend the holidays here. In the winter the boys saw and split the wood. Two or three times each winter the older boys are taken out and shown how to fell trees but practically all this is done by the employees. The older boys are put in charge of a team occasionally and do teamster work. As a reward for good conduct, an older boy is allowed to go out on horseback on the cattle range. Of course he is accompanied and is brought back to spend the night here. The older boys help brand, vaccinate, castrate, dehorn etc. The man who butchers always has two boys who are taught to skin the animal and cut it up. Medium sized boys, from 12-14 help butcher the pigs. Twelve boys milk the cows, feed the calves, operate, feed and care for the cows. This is done under the supervision of the dairyman who shows them how to treat sick animals. Except for the milking, all this is done during the work period. In the evening milking is done in recreation time. The milkers are paid with hockey goods during the winter.

Sixteen or seventeen boys, in turn, look after the pigs, sort potatoes and other vegetables during the work period. In the summer, the smaller and some of the medium sized boys are employed in the garden.

I do not know whether I should mention trapping. We have a pest of groundhogs. The boys are supplied with traps and paid two cents per tail.

All like ranching work and most like farming. Some do not like carpentry but all are given a chance to learn at least the rudiments. Those who show an aptitude are given a good training. I feel that a heavy financial loss to the Manual Trainer has been a great benefit to us as it has brought him here.

II. The Girls.

A/ Baking. Sister Trinity, age about 35, is in charge. She received training in this subject before coming here and has had several years experience.

Every week six girls, two older, two about 13 and two about 10, are taken, in turn, from the classroom and sent three to the bakery and three to the kitchen. The bakers make all the bread, cakes, pies, etc., jellies and other desserts that are made, the butter, etc. I might point out that visitors are surprised at the bread and that one of them always takes a couple of loaves home.

After 3½ days in the bakery, the three girls exchange places with the cooks. Of these Sister Veronica, aged about 30, is in charge. She received training before coming here and has several years experience. Under her direction, the girls do the cooking. One of the severest punishments we can inflict on a girl is to deprive her of her turn in the kitchen or bakery. This is one of the incentives to have them make up for the week they spend out of the classroom.

The smaller girls help peel potatoes and prepare vegetables. Incidentally, the girls are shown what to do should they burn themselves, should anything catch fire, etc.

C/Gardening. Sister Superior is in charge of the little they do. All who wish, and there are quite a few, have their individual flower beds. During the summer holidays, the girls who stay here, that is those to be discharged and any others who are kept here, do a good deal of the gardening. This year, at the request of some of the parents, I had the girls sack the potatoes. That will be part of their work after they leave school. It was a picnic for the girls. They did not do all of it.

D/The girls do not milk. There are several difficulties in the way and it seems prudent to make no change at present.

E/Laundry work. Sister Gonzales, with other Sisters to help, is in charge. All the work is done by hand; it is hard and not liked but the girls show an excellent spirit. As a reward, several are chosen each month.
Cariboo Indian Res. School,
Report of Vocational Training,
1934

"Aundry work
to do the employees' washing and I pay them for this. I believe that the local Agent and the School Inspector urged certain improvements but the Department has not been in a financial position to grant them.

I said that all the work is done by hand. This is not exact. We have one family sized electric washing machine.

"F/ewing, mending, darning, knitting, crocheting, embroidery, fancy work, etc. Sister Gonzales in charge; Sister John Baptist, assistant; Sister Superior, assistant for fancy work. These sisters are fully competent and have about 30 years experience, except for Sister J. Baptist who is about 35.

The younger girls do the darning and the easier mending.

The older girls make their dresses, aprons, summer bloomers, miniskirts, waists, etc. All the boys' clothes are bought, except those which every older girl makes in preparation for eventualities. Each girl is taught to make clothes for babies and small children, even the small girls are taught to knit stockings; the older ones knit shawls, sweaters, etc. Their fancy work is good. They do a little buckskin work.

"General housework, such as sweeping is done by both girls and boys. The girls do the dish washing.

We try to give a training that will be useful after the children leave School. There is an evidence in the houses of ex-pupils that this training has an effect. I have seen it and some of the older Indians have spoken to me about it. There are, of course, cases which could be adduced against this statement. On the whole, however, I believe that what the Department and we are doing is far from wasted money and effort.

Last year (1932-1933), the children's work, in all departments, took prizes at the Kamloops Fair. Of these prizes, only one was as low as third. This year we did not exhibit, except for what we put into the William's Lake Agency booth (and this caused favorable comment). We exhibited, however, at Williams Lake, and got most of the prizes in those departments. We entered in open competition against the white population, our boys and girls took several prizes, not a few of which were firsts although the children, some of whom were 12 or younger, had to compete against grown-up white men and women. We entered a general exhibit, on which there was no prize, but which was a good advertisement. At the banquet at the close of the Fair, the speeches showed that many eyes had been opened and the Agent and School were thanked for making the Fair a success and were highly complimented. This gave me an opportunity, the Agent being away at one of the Reserves, to tell those present the aim, the efforts and the costs of the education of Indian pupils.

Should further information be required, kindly notify me.

I am sending in this report earlier than you requested as I shall be very busy after March 31st.

Trusting that this will not inconvenience you,

I remain yours truly,

Geo. J. Ross
Principal."

Dear Sir:

When I made out my quarterly returns for the quarter ended Oct. 1st, I noticed that I had not sufficient forms for the following quarter and I immediately applied through Mr. Indian Agent Taylor, for these forms. He applied for them but when I asked him for these forms, Dec. 31st, he informed me that these forms had not arrived and he immediately telegraphed for them. I received them two days ago and consequently, my returns are late.

At the same time, I asked for the Manual trainer's salary; it has not yet come. I refer to the salary for the quarter ended Oct. 1st.

REPORT ON WILLIAMS LAKE AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF FEBRUARY, 1943.

Mr. H.A. MacArthur, Provincial Inspector of Schools,

inspected the Cariboo Indian School on the 18th and was rather critical of some aspects of its operation which I am inclined to agree with. In order to stimulate more interest in vocational training I would suggest for a start, two potato clubs, one for the boys and one for the girls. The Department is being requisitioned for one ton of certified seed potatoes, which will supply 20 children with one sack of seed each.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
March 13, 1943.

Reverend Sir:

In reporting on his inspection of the Cariboo Indian Residential School on the 18th ultimo, Mr. H. McArthur, Inspector of Schools, writes as follows regarding vocational training:

"In this school all pupils spend the whole of every Monday and two hours of every other weekday, including Saturday, at farm and household tasks. There is no wood-working department, and no provision is made for craft work or any kind.

"Insofar as I could learn, no vocational clubs of any kind are operated; no steps are taken to coordinate outside jobs with classroom teaching; and no organized attempt is made by outside supervisors to carry out specific educational aims.

"Although this programme is doubtless far from valueless, its defects are obvious. While it gives opportunities for pupils to pick up a variety of skills, it does not insure an understanding of principles, and it seems to leave the matter of interest largely to chance.

"I hope to have an opportunity of discussing with Principal McGrath methods of improving it. (Owing to a death in his family Principal McGrath was unfortunately absent during my visit.)"

Rev. J. McGrath, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Cariboo Indian Residential School,
150 Mile House, B.C.
I should appreciate receiving, as soon as possible, your comments regarding the Inspector's remarks. In reviewing our file I find that for some years past we have been allowing an amount of $50.00 a month toward the salary of the manual training instructor. The last payment we were requested to make in this regard was for the quarter ended March 31, 1942. Are we to infer that you have not employed any manual training instructor since that time?

Under separate cover you are being sent another letter with regard to other remarks of the Inspector.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa,
March 13, 1943.

Mr. Wm. Christie, Indian Agent, Williams Lake, B.C.

I note from your February report that you have heard Mr. McArthur's criticisms of the vocational training at the Okanagan Indian Residential School. For your information I enclose a copy of a letter which is being directed to the Principal and no doubt you will have an opportunity of discussing the whole matter with him.

I note your suggestion to start potato clubs, one for the boys and one for the girls. While you do not say so exactly, I infer that you mean the children in the residential school. If so, have you consulted the Principal with a view to ascertaining if land will be available? Have you also discussed with him the area which each pupil should be encouraged to cultivate? The Department feels that one sack of seed for each child is too much. Have you considered the possibility of a garden plot in which the potatoes would be planted and cared for by two or three children? In suggesting this project I presume you not only wish to encourage growing potatoes, but you desire the work to have some permanent training value for the children concerned. If you start on too large a scale the work involved will be such that the children will be inclined to feel that it is drudgery rather than something in which they are anxious to participate. If that condition arises, the training value is lost. It would, therefore, be appreciated if you would discuss the whole matter with the Principal and let me hear further from you.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Yours file 160-0-11

In regard to your letter of the 13th instant regarding Vocational Training at the Cariboo Indian Residential School, the question of organizing clubs in connection with vocational training has been discussed with the Principal several times and I have given him literature on the aims of these clubs as prepared by the University of Manitoba and also the schedule prepared by the British Columbia Department of Agriculture in connection with the Boys' and Girls' Clubs.

I might say that I have had some experience in organizing calf clubs and potato clubs amongst the White children before becoming an Indian Agent and was rather surprised at the interest of the White children and their parents and also the beneficial results apparent therefrom in an isolated mixed farming community.

At Bella Coola as you may have noted, a potato club was started amongst the Indian children in 1941 which I considered quite a successful beginning. This club was recognized by the Dominion Council of Boys' and Girls' Clubs which was willing at that time at least to recognize similar clubs amongst Indian children on the same basis as Whites, the Provincial Government donating half of the prize money.

In order to have these clubs recognized by the Provincial Government and Dominion Council, it is necessary to adhere to certain regulations. In connection with potato clubs each boy or girl must look after 1/10 of an acre of potatoes, and they recommend one sack of certified seed for each, although this depends to a great extent on the kind of seed potato one is planting—eight sacks are usually sufficient per acre of ground. The ploughing and cultivating need not be done by the children which can be understood, since these clubs are open to boys and girls of from 10 to 21 years.

Another reason for having these clubs on a similar footing to that for White children is that the Provincial Government potato Inspector will inspect the growing crop and also the crop when harvested, pointing out to the children the various diseases.

In the case of calf clubs, pig clubs and poultry clubs assistance is usually willingly given by the Provincial District Agriculturist.

The Cariboo Indian Mission School is ideally situated for the operation of such clubs as they have a large farm, with about 200 acres under cultivation with a possible 400 acres suitable for cultivation. They keep around 800 head of beef cattle, a dairy herd, pigs, chickens, and since the Indians in this Agency depend on agriculture for the most of their living, full...
advantage should be taken of the facilities which could so easily be provided at this school for vocational training suited to them not only in stock raising and grain growing but in the care and operation of farm machinery.

No doubt the children pick up a few things since some of the boys milk and the graduate class of girls each year stay on during the summer holidays and help can vegetables, but there is, as Inspector McArthur pointed out, no organized attempt to co-ordinate class-room work with outside activities. The clubs mentioned would not provide for all the vocational training but they would provide a competitive spirit and their subsequent operation on the Reserves would be an excellent basis of contact after these pupils leave school.

Rev. Fr. McGrath, Principal of this school, came last August and I am afraid he was very badly disappointed in the whole thing; buildings, some of the staff and methods. He has tried hard to get a manual training instructor and a good dairyman without any success so far. One dairyman that he got after looking at the living quarters, returned the same day by the outgoing train.

In discussing these clubs with Father McGrath, I pointed out that I would like to see them started in the Residential School first where adequate supervision could be exercised, picking out pupils from different Reserves. When these pupils returned to the Reserve I intend to use them as leaders in operating similar clubs on the Reserves, thus keeping up the interest and the contacts.

For instance, regarding calf clubs, some of the best clubs could compete at the Annual Williams Lake Cattle Sale held in the Fall and the boys and girls take part in stock judging competitions as is done in most of the fairs in this country. I am satisfied that only through an aggressive program such as this will anything worthwhile be accomplished, and that it is better to concentrate on the Indian Boys' and Girls than on their Parents who are loth to change their old ways.

Although I am personally satisfied that a calf club and potato clubs could be successfully begun at the Cariboo School this year, the Principal's attitude is that he lacks sufficient staff; that he has no dairyman, and secondly in regard to the potato clubs, it is inadvisable to put certified seed in old potato ground and that he will have new land ploughed up this spring or summer for such a project in 1944, so that these clubs would appear to be definitely off for another year.

It is hoped that next year something may be done for the children in the Anahim and Redstone Reserves along this line where Day Schools have been authorized for next Academic year.

The promotion of such clubs in the different Reserves will of course take a lot of the Agent's time until there are competent local leaders and with all the extra work entailed due to the War and no part-time stenographic assistance obtainable it will be difficult to give these projects the time they should have.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
April 6, 1943.

Rev. J. McGrath, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Cariboo Indian Residential School,

Dear Father McGrath:

In further reference to my letter of the 12th instant, I wish to give you a brief outline of our objectives in regard to vocational training and the course in wood work and metal work.

You are aware that a teacher's work is to analyse his pupils, the work to be accomplished, make a selection, teach, test and reteach. The analysis must include the pupil "as is" as well as "as to be". The objectives, therefore, may be summarized:

1. Education must aim at preparing the pupil for a complete life in the sphere of influence in which he will be called to live.

2. To develop manual skill.

3. To provide an opportunity for the developing of creative expression.

Education should be a co-ordination between the classroom and all other training. This is a great means of obtaining the proper motivation which is essential to education.

In order to help you in outlining the work, I am sending the first three years' requirements for woodwork and metalwork. The operations indicated in this work may be carried out in the order most suitable to local conditions.

I am also sending a set of reference books,

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I am in receipt of your letter of Feb 12th as well as your letter and enclosures of Feb. 14th. Thank you very much.

I certainly was very pleased to receive the cheque for $550.00 for refund of Manual Trainer's Salary. Our School funds are quite low at present. Our enrollment has been down this year and on that account we have lost about $1200.00 from the per capita for the last two quarters. I am sure that you realize that the overhead in a school like this is not materially changed by the addition or absence of twenty or thirty children but the loss of the per capita grant for these children has been quite a hardship for us. I have done what I could to bring the enrollment up to our quota and I have asked Mr. Christie to do what he could but the children have been very slow in coming in. The opening of the day school at Anaham has taken away a good number of children who would normally be in school here but even without them I believe there are enough children around in this district of school age to fill the school. I do not think Mr. Christie is in favor of bringing any pressure to bear on the parents of these children for fear they will make trouble.

I was talking to Mr. Christie last night about the lighting plant that we had applied for and he told me that he had just heard from you about it. He said that you were asking if we could pay part of the price of the plant. From what I have mentioned above, I am sure that you will realize that it would be impossible for us. Would it not be possible to allot for that purpose the $1200.00 which was normally to be set aside for this school for the per capita grant? I understand from Major MacKay that this money cannot be forwarded to us as per capita but possibly it could be used to help pay for the plant.

Regarding your enclosed plans for Wood-working and metal work, I was very pleased to receive these. We have started today to put into operation the plans as you have sent them and it will be a great help to the manual trainer in giving the boys a systematized course. I should be glad to receive any further information that you might have along these lines. I have not yet received the reference books you mentioned in your letter but possibly these will be in today's mail (we receive mail only twice weekly).

When I wrote to the Indian Commissioner asking him if he would apply for the balance of our per capita grant for the last quarter, he told me that he did not think there was much chance of getting it but
that the Department might consider re-embursing us for the money we spent in having the laundry floor renewed. This had to be done immediately as it had all caved in and had to be rebuilt before the children returned. The floor was originally made of wood and no air vents had been provided under the floor, with the result that dry rot set in and the floor simply caved in. The new floor is cement and cost us $285.00. This with the $500.00 we paid for the laundry extractor went pretty hard with our school funds. The Commissioner did not mention in his letter if the Department was considering re-embursing us for these two items. I am sure that you will help us out in any way you can and I appreciate very much what you have already done.

Very truly yours,

QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING MARCH 31, 1945, ON WILLIAMS LAKE AGENCY

EDUCATION

Inspector McArthur visited the Cariboo Indian School during March and his report has no doubt been received by the Department by this time. Having been called out to the Chilcotin, I could not accompany Mr. McArthur on his inspection, but following his report, I paid a visit to the School some days later, and paid particular attention to the matters on which complaint was made and had the fire alarm sounded.

The children were very orderly in getting out of the buildings and were all out in under one minute. Fr. McGrath had already taken the locks off all the escape doors, the subject of a very legitimate complaint by Inspector McArthur. It is felt, however, that Mr. McArthur has exaggerated regarding the condition of the boys' dormitory, which has been painted up and is very considerably improved since last year. The improvements in this school since it opened last September have been very considerable, and are as follows:

Equipment: Laundry equipment, consisting of power washer and extractor, saving much time for the girls and improving hygienic conditions.

Vocational: Manual Training classes have been organized. Also Calf Club and Potato Club.

Recreational: The Pro-Rec program has been continued. Three Skating rinks were maintained during the past winter, two for the boys and one for the girls. Hockey games were organized and matches played with boys from the Williams Lake white school.

A boys' fife and drum band has been organized by Brother MacDonald and is making good progress. Brother MacDonald, who commenced duties as disciplinarian last September, has been a great asset to the school, and there has been only one occasion of truancy since last September. The morale amongst the boys was very low during 1943-44 and a number of boys were expelled in June, so that I consider Brother

(over)
Brother MacDonald has done a wonderful job considering the bad feeling amongst the boys which had to be overcome.

Indian Agent.

Reverend Sir,

The attention of the Department has been directed to the inadequacy of the milk supply furnished the pupils of the Cariboo Indian Residential School. It is stated that, while the children are being well fed, they are not getting a sufficient quantity of milk. I should be pleased if you would inform the Department what steps you are taking to provide more milch cows in order to provide sufficient milk for the daily needs of the pupils. I would point out that, especially in the case of the younger pupils, milk forms a most important item of their daily diet. Your early reply regarding this matter is requested.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Mr. H.G. Penrose, Manager of the Lord Exeter Estate was here about a week ago. He has a thoroughbred Helford bull for sale, for which he paid $500 dollars about 5 years ago. As all his stock now is practically related to this bull, he wishes to dispose of it and sell him to our Institution for $400.00.

I would purchase him, had I the means, and leave him with our milch cows. It would be a saving for our school, as we could raise good bulls to supply our range cattle. As you know, we depend mainly on our range cattle to supply our children with meat throughout the year. Nearly every week we butcher from our own stock—that means a great saving to us.

As you are acquainted with the conditions of the Cariboo, I thought it best to write to you and ask you kindly to recommend my request to the proper authorities in Ottawa.

A. F. MacKenzie Esq.,
Act. Asst. Deputy Secretary
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter regarding the milk supply for our children, I wish to tell you that as far as I am concerned I have done my best. Twice a day we give our children every ounce of milk we get from our 15 cows. They are all range cows and very hard to milk. Still we manage to fill our large milk cans and over.

Milk is not separated and the whole milk is given to the children.
When I came here two years ago, the milk was separator—we made our own butter. I stopped it all and whatever milk we received was given to the children. We buy our butter from Vancouver.

What we need here is a herd of milch cows. If the Department is prepared to help us, we would be very pleased. Rev. Fr. Locicola visited me the other day and told me that he expected a few milch cows from the Department. It has been done for other schools—Saskatchewan school and others have been assisted.

A good many of our children are stunted when they first arrive here. Dr. Stone remarked the difference between the younger pupils and the older ones. He was pleased to see the latter healthy, strong and fat and told me that this was an excellent evidence to show that our children are well fed.
I am very pleased that somebody drew the attention of the department to question our milk supply. It is a very serious matter on which depends the future welfare of the Cariboo Indians. They are all more or less weaklings.

I cannot do more than I have done—every day I supervised the milking myself and saw to it that the milk was distributed to the children.

But we have no real milk cows—I wish the department would assist us and give us four or five Holstein cows—and a bull not related to them. This would give us a good start and help us to build up the general condition of the Cariboo Indians.

Thanking you for your inquiry,

I remain, dear Sir,

Yours devotedly

V. Robert O. M.D.
Principal

94 Drop Forgings

Drop forgings are pieces of steel pounded under powerful steam hammers until all the impurities are driven out, the separate little units completely fused and bound together and then formed into shape. They are infinitely stronger than castings, yet they cost less.

Fully 94 drop-forgings go into the construction of every Allis-Chalmers 20-35 Tractor. They are used in the axle, crankshaft gears, connecting rods, and many other parts where the service is particularly severe. No other tractor has this number of drop forgings—it's costly work. Yet we haven't increased our price.

Improved Valve Construction

Allis-Chalmers now uses a special nitricome valve, extra hard and made of steel forged quickly. A water jacket in the cylinder head completely encircles each valve as close to the head as possible. The valves are made wide, providing maximum cooling. The cylinder head material is very hard, containing 1% nickel.

This type of valve construction has been carefully tested in Allis-Chalmers laboratories and in field work throughout the entire past year. It provides for longer lasting service under the severest service conditions, definitely proving that another achievement in tractor design can be credited to Allis-Chalmers.

Oil Purifier

Used as standard equipment on the Allis-Chalmers 20-35 Tractor for over a year and tested in non-operating, economic, and other accessory. Adds to the life of the motor by thoroughly cleaning all the oil 15 times every hour.

No moving parts—no wear out. Filter element is easily cleaned. Worth the cost of a new tractor itself! Why be satisfied without a Purifier when there's no extra charge for one on the Allis-Chalmers 20-35?

Air Cleaner

Another reason for the long life of the Allis-Chalmers 20-35 Tractor. A double-action air-cleaner that takes ALL the dirt, dust and grit before it reaches the motor.

Directly connected to the breather tank which reaches out above the dust and dirt and to the ground, over the top of the tractor. Centrifugal action and oil-filter screen with no moving parts, squeeze the air clean. Nothing to get out of order or wear out.

Three Main-Bearing Crankshaft

Three big, oversize main bearings support the crankshaft in the Allis-Chalmers 20-35 Tractor. Each bearing is provided with four big studs, making the strongest main-bearing construction that can be built in a tractor.

A full 12½" of main bearing surface is provided on which the drop-forged, chrome vanadium steel crankshaft rests. With this extra-duty construction there is no possibility of bending or warping under heavy load.

Here where the greatest strain comes is the greatest strength in the Allis-Chalmers 20-35 Tractor.

Pressure-Type Lubrication

It is only necessary to put oil in the crankcase of the Allis-Chalmers 20-35 Tractor. A gear-driven pump forces the lubricant through main bearings, connecting rod bearings, piston pins and timing gears.

Every moving part in the motor is thoroughly lubricated at all times. Even the small arms are automatically lubricated through a lead from the pressure system. No worry—a gauge on the dash tells you that the oil pressure is right and that wear and friction don't get a chance on the Allis-Chalmers 20-35.

EDUCATION

Inspector McArthur visited the Cariboo Indian School during March and his report has no doubt been received by the Department by this time. Having been called out to the Chilcotin, I could not accompany Mr. McArthur on his inspection, but following his report, I paid a visit to the school some days later, and paid particular attention to the matters on which complaint was made and had the fire alarm sounded.

The children were very orderly in getting out of the buildings and were all out in under one minute. Fr. McGrath had already taken the locks off all the escape doors, the subject of a very legitimate complaint by Inspector McArthur. It is felt, however, that Mr. McArthur has exaggerated regarding the condition of the boys' dormitory, which has been painted up and is very considerably improved since last year. The improvements in this school since it opened last September have been very considerable, and are as follows:

Equipment: Laundry equipment, consisting of power washer and extractor, saving much time for the girls and improving hygienic conditions.

Vocational: Manual Training classes have been organized. Also Calf Club and Potato Club.

Recreational: The Pro-Rec. program has been continued. Three Skating rinks were maintained during the past winter, two for the boys and one for the girls. Hockey games were organized and matches played with boys from the Williams Lake white school.

A boys' pipe and drum band has been organized by Brother MacDonald and is making good progress. Brother MacDonald, who commenced duties as disciplinarian last September, has been a great asset to the school, and there has been only one occasion of truancy since last September. The morale amongst the boys was very low during 1943-44 and a number of boys were expelled in June, so that I consider Brother

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of 
Patrick CHAH, Pupil No. 226, 
of the Cariboo Indian Residential School at St. Joseph's Mission, 
who died at William Lake Hospital (place) on January 20th, 1939.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

FORM No. 414.

1. On what date did this pupil fall sick or suffer injury? January 16th, 1939.

2. At what time of day? During the afternoon.

5. What medicines were used for this purpose and in what dose or quantity? Salicylates.

6. When was the doctor called? The morning of January 17th, 1939.

7. If the pupil was removed to hospital, at what time was this done and by what means of transport? To hospital, 1 p.m., January 17th, 1939, in Dr. C.E. MacKee's closed car.

8. If the pupil was not removed to hospital, what measures were taken for his or her care at the school?

9. Add any other useful information here.

Michael Murphy, D.M.T.

THE DECEASED PUPIL

I attended Patrick Chah from January 17th, 1959
to date of death. The immediate cause of death was Pneumonia.

MEMORANDUM:

DR. SCOTT,

With reference to that portion of Bishop Murray's letter, which is concerning the Christie Indian Residential School, I may say that the buildings are not fireproof, nor are they very suitable for the purpose of educating Indian children. The original wing has been added to from time to time. On the other hand, I understand that this school is quite habitable yet and, in addition to improvements that the church may have effected, the Department has expended $17,240.00 during the last four years in enlarging the school, providing fire protection, installing water supply, electric light and heating equipment.

Dear Dr. Scott:

Last year His Lordship Bishop O'Donnell wrote to the Department about a new school at Kakawis on the West Coast. It was impossible, it seems, to put the matter through at that time. After the lapse of more than a year, when the need has become even more urgent, I respectfully renew the petition. The present Christie School is in poor repair and it would be a waste of money to try and make it really habitable.

There is no doubt in the mind of anyone, who has visited the antiquated building at Kakawis and who is familiar with schools erected by the Department in the past fifteen years, that a new school building at Kakawis is a real and urgent necessity.

After careful survey of the West Coast, no site is deemed more suitable than the present one. In connection with the school a wharf would have to be built. It is hard to realize the inconveniences to which the school is put for lack of a landing-place. A wharf is feasible at Kakawis, in the opinion of Captain Thompson of the C.P.R. Steamer Norah and of other authorities.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

On a recent visit to Christie School, Indian Agent Frost, referring to some communication he had received from the Department, dropped the remark that I might be instructed to limit the number of pupils in residence to the exact 100 covered by my grant.

I should like to anticipate such action by the Department, if I understood Mr. Frost aright, by begging you to present my request for considerable latitude in this matter of number in actual residence for principally two reasons. In the first place, illness and death in the course of a school year, tend to reduce the number in residence appreciably, and it is but natural that I should contemplate with reluctance the corresponding loss of grant if the initial number is to be restricted to 100. Secondly, such restriction, because of existing conditions on the West Coast, would mean to not a small number of children a complete loss or a tardy enjoyment of the benefits of an education with resulting detriment to themselves and ultimately to the Department. Permit me to assure you that space, dormitory and other, is ample for a considerable number of children over and above the 100 covered by my grant.

Will you, therefore, Mr. Ferrier, please interest yourself in the request expressed above? I recall with satisfaction my conversation with you on precisely this subject in which you revealed a thorough grasp and appreciation of conditions on this Coast, and I feel sure that I may count on you for this favor.

Dear Sir:

The writer has been Principal of Christie Indian Residential School since February, 1929. In the course of these more than five years of experience in Indian affairs on the West Coast, I have frequently had occasion to wonder how it was possible that the injustice that has been perpetrated upon Catholic rights, as regards the Indians on the West Coast, was permitted to continue to exist without anything being done to correct it. It has been suggested to me that very likely this state of affairs exists because those high in authority had never had the matter brought to their attention. It is this suggestion that has prompted my addressing this letter to you, and I do so in the hopes you will interest yourself in having the facts stated investigated and the wrong righted if these facts are found to be as represented.

"Vancouver Island and Its Missions" by the first missionary of the West Coast, Father Brabant, is a reliable chronicle of the beginnings of the missions amongst the Indians of the West Coast and of subsequent events. Unfortunately, only one copy of it is to be found at Christie School and no other seems available; but "Reminiscences of the West Coast of Vancouver Island" by Father Charles Moser, which is little more than a later edition of the work, is being forwarded to you, and in it you will be able to find corroboration of the facts which are mentioned as being at bottom of the injustice to Catholic rights to which this letter would respectfully call your attention.

Summarized, the facts are these:

(1) Catholic priests were the first missionaries on the West Coast arriving in the year 1874;
(2) They labored faithfully under the direction of, and assisted by, their bishop, doing all that could reasonably be expected, considering the times and the circumstances, to civilize and Christianize the natives;
(3) The Catholic Church, as represented by Her Bishop and these missionaries, never deserted the field nor interrupted her activities amongst these Indians.

The injustice to which I would call your attention consists in this: that seventeen years after having found the missions and administered to them amidst much labor and hardship, the Catholic Church should have her field invaded by the Protestant missionary, who must have realized from the fact that, with most of the children baptized Catholic and the adults either already received into the church or being prepared for such a step, he could only entertain hopes of success to the extent that he could prey upon the legitimate preserve of the Catholic Church.
Perpetuating this injustice and its logical consequences to Catholic interests as concerns the northern section of this agency is the United Church Indian Residential School at Ahousaht, which, as Father Brabant, in his original memoirs states was established "between two missions having a resident priest," and which, as these memoirs plainly show, was being, as well as had been, administered to by these priests. There are ten tribes to be found between the village of Opitsaht of the Clayoquot Indian tribe in the vicinity of Tofino at the south, and of Kyuquot, observation of the Kyuquot Indians, to the north. All of these with the exception of Ahousaht are still considered Catholic tribes and are administered to by Catholic priests. The United Church establishment at Ahousaht forms a wedge separating half of the Catholic population to be found in the seven tribes to the north from the other half of the Catholic population formed by the two tribes to the south.

Furthermore, since this school should, from the nature of the circumstances, have but the one tribe of Ahousaht to draw from for its children, the result can easily be conjectured. As its numbers begin to decrease, it will be forced more and more, if numbers in attendance are to justify its existence, to prey upon the children of Catholic parents and Catholic tribes as it has so much done in the past, as witness the presence at Ahousaht School, when the writer arrived, of one third of the total attendance being children of Catholic parents; and of the presence in the school at the present time of more than ten such.

It is easy to understand, therefore, why controversies, strife, jealousies, difficulties, proselytizing, defections are continually in evidence affording little edification to the natives, retarding and, to a great extent, nullifying the efforts of both the Department and religion to promote the welfare of the Indian.

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]
(Rev.) Victor Hassier, O.S.B.

Dear Sir,

As immediate Superior of the Rev. Victor Rassier, O.S.B., who for the past several years has been Principal of the Christie Indian Residential School of Kekewis, B.C., and as Head also of St. Benedict's Abbey, Mount Angel, Oregon, entrusted with the supplying of men for the same Indian school, I take upon myself the duty of informing you that unavoidable circumstances have forced me to make a change in the personnel of said school.

During the last fifteen months Rev. Victor Rassier has twice reached a crisis in the matter of his health. Each time recovery in a hospital was necessary. About a month ago, his condition having become quite serious, I called him to Portland for a thorough examination at the Medical Clinic. The doctors' verdict was that both the strain of over-work and the difficult climate on the West Coast of Vancouver Island made a change absolutely necessary in order to avoid a still more alarming condition. Regardless of any reluctance I might feel in the matter, I could not but order his removal. Both the members of our own community and the local authorities at the episcopal see in Victoria, B.C., have repeatedly expressed their satisfaction with Rev. Father Victor's management of the school and I feel certain that you are of the same opinion. It is thus to be regretted that any change became necessary.

As a successor to Father Victor in this rather difficult post I have chosen the man whom I honestly adjudge most fitted for the same. He is the Reverend Bertrand McLoughlin, born in Halifax, N.S. He is a young man, enjoys perfect health, and has that stamp of vitality and determination so necessary for those dealing with Indian subjects. I have full confidence in Father Bertrand and feel certain that he will prove efficient and satisfactory in every respect. His Canadian birth will certainly prove an asset also. His present assistant, Rev. Leo Walsh, is also a Nova Scotian.

That your Department will approve this change I have no doubt. It has been made with the interests of the Christie School always in mind. The necessity for the immediate change compelled me to remove Father Victor despite his earlier desire to carry on until May. This was because of his responsibility in the matter of the refund he had been promised by your Department to cover indebtedness.
incurred in making most necessary repairs and improvements in the School. I do not expect that the removal will interfere in any way with the contemplated refunding and assured Father Victor of the same.

If I can assist your Department in the affair of the Christie Indian Residential School at any time, I shall be delighted to do so.

Sincerely yours,
