Dear Dr McGill:

In the name of the pupils, the Staff and in my own name, I wish you a merry Christmas and a happy New Year.

I am pleased to be able to say that Mr Indian Agent Ashbridge has been very courteous and helpful and, on more than one occasion, has put himself to out in order to be of service to us.

The general health of the School is quite good. We have had to ask for the discharge of some medically unfit children and this has prevented us from having our full quota of pupils but this was done in the interests of all concerned.

There are quite a few things in which great improvement is needed but that will come in time. The children seem quite satisfied and, therefore, it will not be so difficult to make certain changes.

A real source of grief is the weather during the rainy season. It has, so far, made it necessary to keep the boys from their manual training during the rainy season and to keep them in the classrooms morning and afternoon. As you are aware, the Department has granted us materials for a manual training shop. It will be divided into two large rooms (with some smaller ones) which will serve as a carpenter shop and a machine shop. I have done my best since coming here to find a man who is both a competent carpenter and a qualified mechanic but have failed. I have had to employ two men and I am going to ask the Indian Agent to request that the Department grant $40.00 per month towards the salary of each. I am aware that this is not a general practice but our case is a peculiar one. In the Cariboo School, I could have some of the boys in the carpenter shop and others working outside in the winter. Here, during the rainy season, I cannot put all the boys (the 7 to 10 year old boys are not included) in the carpenter shop as none of them would then get any training but I can put half of them at carpentry and the other half at machine work or plumbing. A little training in plumbing will be of real use to them. I cannot put any of them to work outside during the rain.

When everything is organized, I hope to be able to let the Indians bring their motors here and have them attended to by the instructor and either themselves or the boys. That will not only save the Indians money but will teach them something about repairing and adjusting their motors.

I bought a small canning machine and, now that we have a good boiler, I hope to have the girls do a little canning. They will learn how to cut up and pack fish and thus prepare for their work in the canneries. The Department suggested that the girls be taught to make fish nets. I have gone into this with the Indians and with other fishermen and have found that it is not practical. What might be practical is to have the girls and boys learn to repair nets.

A rather unfortunate incident arose occurred the other day. A Catholic man and wife (we have the Catholic certificates of their baptism and marriage) asked me to admit their son who had been at the Ahousat School for six or seven years. No one here did anything to induce or to encourage them to take this perfectly right step. They said that they wanted the boy here with his brother and sisters and that they would not allow him to return to Ahousat. I did not want the boy here until his transfer had been approved and, therefore, gladly told the father that I had no objection to the boy returning with the father. The latter told me that he would be away until after Christmas.
unfortunate part of the thing is that, without being announced, the boy arrived on November 23rd before I had been notified of his being transferred. Had I thought of it, I could have paid his fare back to Barclay Sound where his parents were and still are. I would not return him to the Ahousat School because his father and mother are opposed to this and I did not want to impose him on a family in the nearby reserve and, so, I accepted him as a guest until the matter is settled. Mr Caldwell, the Ahousat Principal, informed me over the phone that the boy's being allowed to come here while he was on the Ahousat register. It is not ridiculous but it is deeply regretted by me. What is "ridiculous" is that the boy was admitted to a non-Catholic School. His elder brother was brought up in that school, although he was baptized a Catholic.

I have courteously explained the whole matter to the Indian Agent and to Mr Caldwell and have assured them that the mistake was made in the beginning and that time has not and cannot correct it. I have stated very plainly that I believe that the parents are the ones to blame as I do not imagine (although I have seen many strange things) that the Ahousat School would have accepted the boy had he not been declared eligible for admission on religious and other grounds by his parents. As a matter of fact, he was not eligible. What I regret is that the boy came before the transfer was made.

I need not say that, as I have assured Mr Caldwell, that I have done nothing and will do nothing to get any child out of another School provided that he is rightfully there. Like the Bishop, I will, of course, stand up for our rights.

Provided that both sides try to be absolutely fair, there may be differences of views but there need be no lack of justice or charity.

Again offering you our best wishes,

I remain yours sincerely,

G. Forbes, O.M.I.

Dear Sir:

I have always written in plenty of time for Christmas to the various members of the Department but this time I was caught napping. AGENT'S REPORT ON WEST COAST AGENCY FOR NOVEMBER.

During the recent inspection of schools an incident in connection with fire drills came under my observation, which was worthy of note and possible correction at other schools, which may employ similar methods.

During the daytime a false fire alarm was given by a mischievous boy and the gongs were sounded. Children in classrooms and different parts of the grounds, laundry etc., instead of proceeding quietly to their allotted places clear of the building in the event of fire, immediately rushed to their dormitories inside the building. It was very evident that they had been accustomed to taking their places in the dormitories, awaiting the alarm, when they would march out. Had there been a fire, these children would have walked into it and caused confusion and possible loss of life.

At this particular school, steps have been taken to correct this, and children and staff instructed as to procedure under any circumstances. It is respectfully suggested that school children, especially those housed in wooden buildings, be given practice in descending fire escapes by using the escapes instead of inside stairways daily, when leaving the dormitories in the mornings. Also that wooden fire escapes be well sanded during wet and frosty weather, and that alarms be sounded without previous warning, after the staff and children have been thoroughly instructed in their procedure.

P.B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Neill:

I am in receipt of your letter of June 22, with reference to the per capita allowance of the Christie (Kakawis) Indian Residential School.

For some years past the Department has only included in the annual estimates a percentage of the amount that would be required if all Indian residential schools in Canada had their full enrolment throughout the academic year. This policy was first adopted in the fiscal year 1933-34, at which time the average attendance at all Indian residential schools was only 92% of the authorized enrolment and, therefore, the amount voted was sufficient to meet per capita grant payments.

However, in the last two or three years practically all Indian residential schools have enrolled their full authorized number of pupils and in many cases have been carrying several pupils more than their authorized pupilage. As a result the average attendance at all Indian residential schools for the past year has greatly increased. On the other hand, despite the return last year of the 5% deduction, the percentage of the actual appropriation provided by Parliament remains the same. Consequently, the amount provided for per capita grants will not permit our paying more than 92.24% of the authorized pupilage at any Indian residential school. I regret that this contingency has arisen but due to present conditions it is impossible to remedy it.

Yours sincerely,

N. J. F. Pratt,
Private Secretary.

Sir:

Schools:

Christie Residential School was thoroughly inspected and found to be in first class order.

Fire drill was carried out very satisfactorily. All fire fighting appliances were in good order. The pupils were all in splendid health and were clean, well clothed, well fed, attentive and industrious. Splendid progress is being made in vocational training.

Girls were being taught wool combing, carding, spinning and knitting, and are producing first class sweaters, socks, etc., through every process from sheep shearing to the finished article. In addition they are being taught needlework, cooking, etc.

The boys are being instructed in boat building and repairs, marine engine operation and repair, carpentry etc. Splendid progress is also shown in physical training, and both boys and girls gave a creditable display of gymnastics.

Dear Father Forbes:

Please accept my sincere thanks for your letter of December 26 and for the photographs enclosed therewith.

It is evident, from the appearance of these girls and from the letter received by you from Mr. Eisenhardt, that you are doing splendid work in the development of your pupils physically as well as mentally. I am particularly interested in physical culture or physical development and frequently express regret that we have not been able to do more in the organization of physical culture classes at our residential schools throughout the Dominion.

I read with interest your comments on the dangers associated with the transportation of children to and from the Christie School. These dangers must be very real to you and to the members of your staff. It would appear from the records here, however, that we have been particularly fortunate and that there has been no loss of life reported to the Department at any time in recent years.

It is unnecessary to state that any request you may make in due course for a grant necessary to help you provide for transportation costs will be sympathetically reviewed by the officials of this Branch. I would not be frank with you, however, if I did not state that in my judgment it is going to be exceedingly difficult for us to secure from Parliament the funds required -

Reverend George Forbes, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Christie Indian Residential School,
Kakawin, B.C.
required to maintain our educational institutions in the future in the sense that we have maintained them in the past. We are, as you know, fighting at this time for our survival and almost every service is subordinated to the Nation's war effort. I think you will agree with me that the Government has been very liberal until now in providing educational facilities for the Indian population. With the funds at our disposal limited, with requests for help steadily multiplying and with the Indian pupil enrolment increasing at the rate of approximately 300 pupils per annum, it is not an easy thing to pass judgment and reach decisions on the requests before us from time to time. We do feel, however, that a period as critical as this demands devotion and self-sacrifice on the part of all of us.

I want to thank you very heartily on behalf of the staff here for the work you are doing at the Christie School. Summaries of the reports reaching this Branch, of your school, have been sent forward from time to time to the Minister for his information.

May I embrace this opportunity to wish you, the members of your staff and the pupils in attendance at your school a very happy and prosperous New Year.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

THE EDMONTON CHALLENGE CUP

The handsome cup that the name of that distinguished Mohawk Chief who has taken so singular an interest in the dramatic work of the Indians of this Province, has been awarded this year to the:

Christie Residential Indian School
Kakawin B.C.

for the consistently high standard of the dramatic work accomplished.

Their play "The Hidden Gem," written years ago by Cardinal Wiseman, was an outstanding example of what our Indians are capable of doing under good direction.

The diction, the sincerity of emotional feeling, and the general stage technique made this memorable performance. We congratulate this club on its success, and we hope that some other club or reserve may be able to win the Cup next year. Such good work is being done by the Om-Om-sees Chap-Lee at Inukmeep, who were last year's winners and by the Christie School at Kakawin, that the others will have to work hard in order to carry the laurels to some other part of the Province.

Some photos of the Kakawin Players were exhibited in Eastern Canada recently and attracted general interest.

Dear Mr. Neill:

I am in receipt of your letter of June 28, with reference to the per capita allowance of the Christie (Kakswis) Indian Residential School.

For some years past the Department has only included in the annual estimates a percentage of the amount that would be required if all Indian residential schools in Canada had their full enrolment throughout the academic year. This policy was first adopted in the fiscal year 1933-34, at which time the average attendance at all Indian residential schools was only 95% of the authorized enrolment and, therefore, the amount voted was sufficient to meet per capita grant payments.

However, in the last two or three years practically all Indian residential schools have enrolled their full authorized number of pupils and in many cases have been carrying several pupils more than their authorized pupilage. As a result the average attendance at all Indian residential schools for the past year has greatly increased. On the other hand, despite the return last year of the 5% deduction, the percentage of the actual appropriation provided by Parliament remains the same. Consequently, the amount provided for per capita grants will not permit our paying more than 92.24% of the authorized pupilage at any Indian residential school. I regret that this contingency has arisen but due to present conditions it is impossible to remedy it.

Yours sincerely,

A. W. Neill, Esq., M.P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa.

R. J. F. Pratt,
Private Secretary.
2 B.C. Indian Girls Win Poster Contest Awards

By MILDRED VALLEY THORNTON

Winners of the various prizes in the Victory Contest for 1944 sponsored by the Nathan Foundation have recently been announced. It is the godparent to many worthwhile enterprises for cultural progress and annually offers large sums of money and scholarships for art work of high merit. This year they launched the 18th poster contest for the Promotion of Humane Education.

The animal poster contest is twofold in purpose. It aims to encourage artistic proficiency and to inculcate in children everywhere the love and proper regard for animals and wild life.

This group which is open to grades 1 to 6 drew a great many entries from all over Canada and the United States. Some 135 prizes were awarded. Four of the winners in this class were Canadians, and two out of the four were Indian children living in British Columbia.

People who are concerned with the preservation and encouragement of native art in this province will be gratified at this evidence of existing talent among modern Indian children who are able to hold their own in open competition with white children from the whole of the continent.

Both winners are girls. Annie George is a pupil at the Indian Day School of Penticton, and Helena Titian brings honor to the Christie Indian School at Kakawis, on the West Coast of Vancouver Island.

POINTS TO CONSIDER ON PLANNING CONTEST POSTERS

1. Keep your posters simple in composition. Use large bold areas and rich color schemes.

2. Avoid lettering that is hard to read. Use letters that are bold in character and easily read at a distance.

3. While white or cream paper is good, very effective posters are obtained by using dark colors. Use black, dark blue, deep green, mahogany, dark brown, and black.

4. Do not attempt to put too much in your poster, and make your design fill the space fully. If you use outlines on your designs, make these outlines quite heavy, at least one-eighth of an inch thick.

5. Remember that your poster is not of much value unless it tells the story of your message effectively. A good poster counts in judging the poster contest.

6. It will help considerably if you set your poster up a few yards away and see if it carries well. Good posters should be easy to read at a distance of ten feet or more.

Having just completed a tour of inspection of schools and hospitals, I feel that I should bring to the attention of the Department a matter which will present itself within a year or so.

I refer to the conditioning of Christie Residential School.

This school was built forty-five years ago, facing the sea, of wood frame construction, and while it has been very well cared for, it is fast approaching the stage where re-building is indicated, or at least extensive repair and maintenance.

It would appear that when the present site was chosen, the matter of transportation and landing of supplies was entirely overlooked; as the only facilities for landing supplies is by canoe and surf boat, which is a great hardship, and at times dangerous.

My reason for broaching this matter is that the Air Force Hospital situated at Long Beach, a few miles from Kakawin, is now closed and would make an ideal school if it could be transferred to the Department or taken over by the Church.

Situated within easy reach of Tofino and Ucluelet, on a new highway, it is far better than the present site, insofar as transportation is concerned.

The building has a capacity of 125 beds, and is well finished inside, and it is thought that no time should be lost in making application for its transfer, pending further investigation.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter, file 159-0-1, dated 18th January, 1946, in which you make enquiries as to the availability of the RCAF hospital at Tofino for use as an Indian Residential School.

This hospital is situated a few miles from RCAF Station, Tofino, and was constructed as a casualty hospital during the Japanese threat of 1942. It was to be available for all Services.

Plans indicate that there will be no further requirement for a hospital of this size in the area, insofar as this Department is concerned.

It is the intention of this Department, therefore, to declare the hospital surplus to requirements. Provided the Departments of National Defence (Naval Service and Army) have no requirement for the facilities and that the Wartime Committee on Hospitalization does not consider the hospital is required to continue in operation as such, the building will likely be made available to your Department through the Crown Assets Allocation Committee.

I would suggest, therefore, that you file application with that Committee to acquire the hospital in question, if and when it becomes available.

If the building becomes available to your Department, being a Federal Government Department, the Crown Assets Allocation Committee would dispose of it by direct allocation without reference to the War Assets Corporation, so that the matter of costs would not enter into this transaction, except for bookkeeping purposes.

Dear Mr. Glen:

I am advised that your Department has been considering the purchase of the RCAF hospital at Tofino, B.C. as a possible site for the Christie Indian Residential School, which is presently located at Kakawis, B.C., and it was intended, if you went ahead with this project, that the Kakawis School would be abandoned and the students transferred to the RCAF hospital at Long Beach, Tofino.

You are probably not aware that this hospital site is on the famous Long Beach which has long been held as a possible tourist resort, and that the property on which this hospital is located was donated as a patriotic gesture by Mr. A. C. Lovekin, who owns considerable adjoining property. It is felt that this property should not be sold by the War Assets Corporation to your Department for Indian Residential School purposes, as there is no doubt that such a course would prejudice the value of the adjoining property for summer resort purposes.

I had already written to the Principal, Father Mulvihill, of the Christie's Indian Residential School, suggesting that he would be better advised to have his school located at Ucluelet, where the War Assets Corporation have numerous buildings suitable for his purpose, and where there is also agricultural ground which the Tofino site does not have.

I would appreciate it very much if you would have your officials allow me to make representations before

(over)
any final decision is made in this regard, as I believe that Mr. Lovekin is entitled to every consideration.

Thanking you, I am,

Yours very truly,

J. L. Gibson

Dear Mr. Yates:

I have hesitated to reply to your letter of June 3rd until now in the hope that I would secure additional information with respect to the establishment of an Indian residential school on the hospital site at Long Beach, Vancouver Island.

It would appear that a well-equipped residential school building is urgently needed in this particular district. The proposal now under consideration is that the present buildings be transferred to this department and that the buildings when transferred be used for residential school purposes. If such a transfer were made, the property would of course remain the property of the Crown in the right of the Dominion, although the school itself would be operated by a religious order, probably the Oblate Order.

Is it Mr. Lovekin's desire that the buildings should be dismantled and removed from the site, or is he prepared to allow the buildings to remain and be used for purposes other than the education of the Indian children of the district? In this connection, I may state that it is somewhat unusual to have an objection to the establishment of an Indian residential school in any district; in fact, petitions reach us from time to time for the establishment of such schools in or near comparatively large centres. The Mohawk Institute at Brantford, Ontario, for example, is located in the city of Brantford, and the Brandon residential school is close to the city of Brandon.

Since the Indian Department has not succeeded in acquiring the RCAF Hospital at Long Beach on the west coast of Vancouver Island for an Indian Residential School, the Indian Commissioner for B.C. suggested that I bring this to the attention of the Joint Committee of Parliament, as the Department represents a public institution, while private interests are represented by Hon. J.L. Gibson M.P., who is opposing the application of your Department.

The Indian Commissioner told me the present school is very old, and would cost about two or three hundred thousand dollars in the very near future to build a new school.

This expenditure would not be necessary were the Department able to acquire the hospital in question.

Will you please exert every effort to defeat the rapacious hand of the exploiter, so that the public's funds will not be given to private benefits because as a public institution, we have a more legitimate claim.

This acquisition would place the school in Government property, whereas the present school site belongs to the Roman Catholic Church.

Please advise me of your decision in this matter, and thanking you in anticipation of your usual great interest in such matters, but I must express my regrets that I did not see you, when I testified before the Joint Committee of Parliament on the Indian Act.

Respectfully yours,

Andrew Paull

To the Honourable Members
Special Joint Committee
Of the Senate and the House of Commons
On the Indian Act.

Honourable Gentlemen—

I have been advised, and I consider it to be imperatively necessary as a public duty to make a sincere appeal to your Honourable Committee, to take such action as may be necessary at your most early convenience, so that the former RCAF Hospital at Long Beach on the west coast of Vancouver Island in the province of B.C., may be transferred to the Department of Indian Affairs to be used as an Indian Residential School.

The present Indian Residential School is not far away, in an old building a fire trap, and not accessible by road, and when the seas are rough it is impossible to land food and other supplies.

This hospital has been applied for by the Indian Department, but I am told that some citizens of the district are opposing it, with the view of acquiring the buildings for private enterprise.

If this hospital is not now acquired, public funds to the amount of at least $200,000.00 would have to be spent to build a new school, to replace the present antiquated and dilapidated school.

There is no reason in my opinion why public funds should be so spent, for the benefit of private enterprise, and I am told that the opposition by those desiring the place is so strong that I have been advised to appeal to your Committee, so that you may take the necessary action for the immediate acquisition by the Indian Department before the children return from their holidays.

The acquiring of the hospital as an Indian Residential School will be in the public interest, if only for the sake of economy, and beg for your very sympathetic action.

I am told that the application by the Indian Department has so far failed because of the opposition by private interests.

Thanking your Honourable Committee in anticipation of your favorable action, have the honour to be,

Respectfully yours

Andrew Paul
President
North American Indian Brotherhood.

Dear Sir:

My client, Mr. A. C. Lovekin, of Long Beach,
Vancouver Island, B.C., donated a ten-acre parcel of
land to the Crown for the purpose of use as a hospital
in connection with the Royal Canadian Air Force Station
at Long Beach. This donation was consummated by a Con-
veyance of the said ten acres, being a part of Lot 162,
on which Mr. Lovekin's own home is situated.

Recently it has been brought to my attention that
the said ten-acre parcel of land was being considered
through the Department of Indian Affairs as the site for
an Indian Residential School. I have written to the
Member of Parliament for the Constituency in which this
land is situated, and to several other persons asking that
steps be taken to prevent the use of the said property for
that purpose. If your Department does not require the ten
acres donated by Mr. Lovekin for Hospital purposes, I feel
that it is only fair that the land be reconveyed to him,
and further I feel very strongly that it should not on any
account be used for Indian Residential School purposes, as
such use would definitely depreciate the value of the
remainder of his property to a serious degree.

As a result of my letters referred to above, I
have received a letter from the Director of Indian Affairs

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of July 4th, 1946, enquiring as to whether it was Mr. Lovekin's desire that the building should be dismantled and removed from the site, I have to say that Mr. Lovekin has no desire to see this done at this time, but if that were the only alternative to a mission school then decidedly his wish would be to have the buildings removed.

However, as I pointed out in my former letter, it is contended that inasmuch as the property was donated by Mr. Lovekin to the Crown for hospital purposes, and in the belief that it would be permanently used for that purpose, the Crown should reconvey the property to him now that it is no longer required for that purpose. Any other use or disposition of the land would be most unjust.

I can quite understand that petitions reach your Department for the establishment of mission schools comparatively near large centres. The two situations however are entirely different. In Mr. Lovekin's case, out of loyalty he donated a ten acre parcel of waterfront property out of the same lot on which he had built his home, which is situated on one of the most desirable locations on Long Beach.

Any school established on this property would most decidedly deteriorate the value of his remaining home property. Residents of the area agree on this subject and some of them have also written to the Member of Parliament representing Alberni District voicing strong protest. The Member himself, knowing the situation at Long Beach agrees with them on this subject as he has stated by letter to me.
In your letter you state that if the buildings should be transferred to the War Assets Corporation they would probably be sold by tender to the highest bidder. I understand that the matter is already in the hands of the Crown Assets Allocation Committee according to a letter received from the Deputy Minister of National Defence for Air. In the event that the War Assets Corporation takes over the buildings and can dispose of them only under bids received, Mr. Lovekin might consider making a bid. Mr. Lovekin's son is making a journey to Long Beach and will report on his inspection of the buildings on his return to Victoria. It is expected that the son will make his inspection during the next thirty days and I will be writing the Crown Assets Allocation Commission on his return.

In closing I wish to make it clear that Mr. Lovekin is primarily concerned with the use of the land and that if the Crown abandons its use as a hospital site, it should not put the land to any other use but should reconvey it. If the Crown should, however, wish to dispose of the buildings by public tender, that is satisfactory to Mr. Lovekin so long as the title to the land is reconveyed to him. Any bid to be submitted by Mr. Lovekin will be dependent upon the report made as to the value of the buildings from Mr. Lovekin's viewpoint.

Yours truly,

Re: Improvements to Kakawis School, B.C.
Attention: Mr. P. Phelan.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

As you know, this school through possibly no fault of the Department, was poorly situated, as far as sea approach to it is concerned. It appears that the surf and the waves, during storms and the Winter season, are so strong that it has been found inadvisable to build a wharf or any kind of protection for boats having freight to unload.

At the present time, all freight is loaded at Tofino in the large mission boat, then unloaded in a barge or smaller row-boat and carried by the school help to shore. This method of freighting applied to all visitors as well. I am informed that, due to the hardship of reaching Kakawis, your Commissioner has never visited the school.

You will admit that this condition create hardships which it is hardly fair to ask a Principal and school staff to bear indefinitely.

One method, and possibly the only one to improve these conditions, would be the building of a road from the school to the Indian village where wharfage could easily be secured and boats tied in safety. I believe that such a road might be build for at most $10,000. The distance is not more than two miles and $5,000 per mile would be a very fair price. I would therefore ask the Department to include this amount in next year's estimates.

The pupilage is inferior to the capacity of the school and should be increased. The number of pupils in the neighborhood who are asking for admission is quite large and an increase of 20 pupils would partially answer their demand. I would therefore ask the Department to also include a sufficient amount for this purpose in next year's estimates.
It has been found impossible in this school to keep cows or horses, due to the fact that all feed for them had to be brought from long distances and at prices quite prohibitive in relation to the service they could render. As a result it has been found impossible even to grow potatoes or cultivate a garden. If the Department could supply a small tractor and plow, quite a quantity of fresh vegetables could be given to the children and I hope that you will also provide for the purchase of the above in your next year's estimates.

There are smaller items which your Commissioner might be asked to supply, such as books for the library and a few new sewing machines.

Thanking you in anticipation I remain

Very truly yours,

(Sgd) J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

April 14, 1947

Mr. B.F. Henry M.B.E.
Dept. of Welfare & Training
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir -

I am submitting a request for an increase in the quota of pupils for this school. The present quota is 110 children. We have 115 children attending at present and of this number 102 should return to school in September. This means that we could only accept eight children to bring our population up to quota requirements. During the past year I have had to refuse many parents the right to send their children to school. There are more than thirty-five children of school age, Catholic parents, who wish to come to school. I mention only those who have asked to send their children to school - eight children from the
Kyugust tribe, seven from Clayquot, eight from Hesquiat, eight from Uootka Sound, and five from the Keltsewat tribe. I have their names and ages on file, some are nine or ten years old, and have not had the opportunity of attending school. This school has enjoyed a very good reputation among the Indians for some years now but nothing can ruin the reputation of a school on this coast as quickly as disgruntled parents who have been refused a request to send their children to school—they take it as a personal insult.

This school, as you know, has no farm or garden and all supplies have to be shipped in by boat. It is quite expensive to run and we cannot afford to accept very many free boarders over our quota. If the quota could be raised to 125 it would take care of the older children wishing to come to school. I do not ask for any permanent increase, only as a temporary measure until the question of Indian education has...
Christie Indian Residential School
Kakawis, B.C.
(WEST COAST, VANCOUVER ISLAND)

I am making this request now because some alterations would have to be made and room found for another classroom. This would entail expenses which we could not afford unless we were certain of an increase in per capita expenditures. The cost of living at this school has increased in the past five years to the amount of $250 without any increase in grant. These figures are only for basic foods, there has been a similar increase in wages, fuel, and house equipment. We are no longer able to carry children above the quota.

The increase in grant brought by fifteen pupils would pay for the extra teacher we would need. With a few alterations we could accommodate fifteen more children who otherwise would be without schooling.

Hoping to receive a favourable answer to this request - I remain

Yours truly,

Dear Father Mulvihill:

I have your letter of April 14th. The new per capita grants will be paid as from January 1, 1947. We have just written today to the Reverend Father Plourde informing him of the increase in the per capita grants to the various schools maintained by the Oblate Order. I can give you advance information that your school will receive an emergency grant of $40.00 per pupil which will bring your total per capita grant to $235.00.

I presume that this will give you the additional funds which you require. The question of increasing the pupilage of a school is a very difficult one. It would be necessary for Inspector of Schools, Mr. Davey to submit a report upon the dormitory accommodation available at your school before such an increase would be considered. If you still wish to press for such a change, would you please write to him so that the problem can be discussed when he visits your school.

Yours truly,

Bernard F. Neary,

Sir,

In answer to your letter of the 13th September 1896 enclosing copy of letter from the Rev. P. Maurus Principal of the Bishop Christie Roman Catholic Boarding School, Clayoquot with reference to the insufficiency of the water supply for that institution I have the honour to report that the present water supply is brought from a creek adjacent by means of a dam across the stream and a small hydraulic ram; the present water system including piping, tank &c cost the management some $1600. The dam is faulty and leaks and though every effort has been made to remedy this it has been without success also in the summer months the water in the dam becomes stagnant and charged with more or less vegetable matter and also fails in quantity to keep the ram working so that during the dry season water has to be fetched in buckets up the hill to the School buildings, to remedy this and improve the
present system would require a new dam some 1000 yards further back (this stream running through comparatively level ground) and would entail 3000 feet more piping which would be an expensive undertaking and not satisfactory; The Rev Principal therefore proposes to bring water by iron piping from another stream, a never failing spring of pure water situated on the side of the hill behind the Mission, as there is little or no surface water draining into this stream, even in the rainy season, the water is always pure and varies little in volume summer and winter, on the side of the hill where the connection would be made the stream is 1/2 to 2 feet wide and 4 to 6 inches deep, so that a dam would not be required, only a box to guide the water into the pipe; the claimed distance from the Mission buildings is 3500 feet with about 85 feet fall so that the water would flow into the tank above the buildings with the pressure produced by at least 40 feet fall, or into the lower floor of the school with a pressure from 80 feet fall, and would give a continued and plentiful supply of water for fire fighting or any emergency.

The piping required, and cost delivered at the School would be
3500 feet 2 inch galvanized iron piping f.o.b. Victoria at $19 per ft. 691.25
T joint 1.50
Wharfage Victoria on 6 tons 3.25
Freight Victoria to Clayquot 26.00
$722.00

The Principal applies to the Department to grant the cost of this piping; he would undertake the work, the pipes would merely require screwing together and could be laid along the ground at little expense with the aid of the bigger lads in the School and they would have a plentiful and lasting supply of good fresh water.

In view of the undoubted efficiency of the School, that at the present time there are 55 pupils inmates of the institution, 5 more than the capita grant allows for, and others have been refused admission owing to want of accommodation and that the management hope to make an addition to the building to provide for more scholars I would strongly urge that the Department receive the application favorably.

I have the honor to be

Dear Sir:

To my greatest consternation I learn today from the Indian Agent, Mr. Neile, that the allowance which you kindly secured for our institution for a permanent water supply would lapse with end of the fiscal year unless the work be in some stage of advancement. Were I not sure that the oversight of not informing me of this condition was due to Mr. Guillod's illness, I should feel very much aggrieved over it.

In point of fact I had an expert from Victoria out here in May looking over the grounds; another party I had engaged to locate the tank, I myself leveled, surveyed and measured the pipe line. To save expense I did not want to begin operations before the rainy season came to a close, unfortunately very late this year. As I had agreed to do the work with some of the pupils, I did not consider it advisable or practicable to send the boys out in the rain into the wet woods and into the then existing swamps. Since July the pupils have slashed a good distance of the trail through the woods where the pipe line goes through. In about a week the trail will be finished and we shall then be ready to lay the pipe in case the pipe will arrive in time. I have the order for pipe & other material placed in the hands of my representative in Victoria a month ago, but have not heard from the party if he actually awarded the order to any of the bidders or not. Of course, had I been forewarned & been reminded of the Department's rule regarding such allowances, I should not at all have delayed placing the order for the required material before the expiration of the fiscal year. While I am not versed in prices of this class of plant enough to pronounce an opinion as to the value of the work at the price stated, yet it must be assumed that as so large a part of the price had to be borne by the Church, that the Principal no doubt got the work done as economically as possible consistent with efficient work. I can, however, certify that the work appeared to have been carried out faithfully according to the contract & that the result is a complete & very efficient system of heating the whole building. The 48 radiators are suitable for the purpose & properly distributed throughout the building with the usual appliances for cutting off the heat from any individual radiator. The system had been in operation several days before my visit & had been, and was, working quite satisfactorily.

I have therefore pleasure in recommending payment of the vouchers for the sum of $1500.00 as stated.

Dear Sir,

I have the honor to inform you and the Department that our institution very badly needs better accommodations for laundry purposes. The necessity of a larger laundry makes itself felt not only at present, but has been apparent from the very date the school was opened seven years ago. Just like the main (first) building it had been designed too small. In a space of 13 x 22 feet eighteen to twenty pupils have to do the washing with part of this space being occupied by the laundry stove. The remaining portion of the present laundry is taken up by a drying closet and stove, which drying system though, I may be permitted to mention right here, is an utter failure.

While painfully aware of these insufficient and imperfect conditions for the whole time of my incumbency, I had contemplated to better them as soon as the necessary additions for the proper housing of the pupils and the employees should be completed. Though the latter object is accomplished, still I am not in a position, owing to a considerable indebtedness for buildings and equipment, to provide sufficient laundering facilities for at least two years to come. For this, I appeal to the Department for aid to enable me to do this and I most urgently ask for an appropriation of fifteen hundred dollars for the purpose.

The building of the proposed laundry of 25 x 56 feet will cost at least $957.48 for material alone without extra labor.

The equipment of necessary labor saving appliances will cost from four hundred fifty dollars to five hundred dollars.

The total cost of material alone without allowing anything for extra labor will be in the neighborhood of fifteen hundred dollars.

A detailed estimate of material and appliances I hereby enclose.
I beg to explain however that I do not consider myself infallible in the preparation of this estimate as I had to make it myself without assistance of competent partners and it may want correction for all I know, although I made it to the best of my knowledge and according to information I was able to obtain with no mean difficulty. This difficulty of obtaining information is responsible for the delay of submitting the estimate at an earlier date.

Of course it is my intention to have the work done by the instructor and his apprentices, but for brick work it will be necessary to hire extra help.

When I ask for an equipment of some laundrying appliances I do not want you or the Department to infer that hand washing is to be replaced by machine work. By no means, but I think that the boys, especially the large ones on whom falls the burden of washing, might be more profitably employed at trades or clearing land the two or three half days whenever the heavier washing is to be done.

With the present facilities, once a month from a hundred to a hundred and twenty bed sheets are to be washed, they should be washed however twice a month. Every two weeks some sixty night gowns, forty girls' (over-all) aprons, thirty boys' jumpers, and every week in addition to the regular week's washing some twenty overalls require washing.

The appliances asked for are intended only to save time and labor, and with the use of them for the heavier washing the pupils will not be dispensed with from the usual week's washing.

During the wet season it is practically impossible to dry the clothes in the open air, and a drying closet is an imperative necessity for this country. I installed a dryer, made in Montreal, six years ago at a cost of two hundred dollars but the system
has never given the least satisfaction. The draws however can be used for the new dryer and save that portion of the expense. The draws are not included in the estimate for new dryer.

Regarding the Hand Power Extractor, this is not an absolute necessity, but it is a most useful and economical machine saving labor and clothes, and drying clothes to a degree not attained by any kind of common wringer. Because it wrings out the clothes almost dry, I consider it a desideratum for our wet climate. The estimate is for the heaviest hand power machines, there are cheaper and inferior ones in the market.

I beg to state that the estimate of laundry appliances is not absolutely correct, but it is as nearly so as I could make it from catalogues of Chicago firms. Unfortunately I have not been able to secure catalogues and prices from Canadian (Toronto) houses. Again the allowances for freight may vary slightly.

Commending this my respectful application for grant for a new laundry and its equipment to your serious and favorable consideration, I have the honor to remain, dear Mr. Agent,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

Since writing my application for a grant of fifteen hundred dollars for the erection and equipment of a new laundry, Mr. Robt. M. Ogilvie, Architect of the Indian Department, has been here on a visit, and he advised a low pressure steam system for operating the dryer and providing hot water and boiling of clothes.

If low pressure steam does not come under the law requiring a licensed engineer or fireman, of course this system is far superior to a heating system by stove of the dryer as well as to boiling clothes in the old fashioned wash boiler and much quicker in operation.

The steam generator would then supersede the drying and hot water heating stove and also the clothes boiler with necessary brick work. The location of the steam generator or boiler in consequence entails an alteration in the division of the space of the building.

In any case I would respectfully request that plan of the laundry building, interior arrangement, etc., be submitted to Mr. Ogilvie, of whose absolute competency I am fully convinced.

LETTER NO. 249-12.

SIR,

With reference to the grant under authority File No. 181,717/5 dated August 10th, 1908 or $1500.00 to purchase material for the erection of a laundry at the Clayoquot Industrial school, I have the honor to forward herewith application from the Rev. P. Maurus, principal of the school for a further grant to complete the actual cost of the plant.

The principal's figures are correct as per his letter with the exception that he has omitted in the payment made by the Dept. to Woods Bros (otherwise the Barclay Sound Cedar Co.) the freight paid by them on their shipment of lumber. This would make their account $330.35, a difference of $62.95. Consequently the figures subsequent to that entry are wrong to that extent and the correct figures are those marked by me in red ink.

Consequently the total expenditure incurred is $1935.04, and the excess over the grant is $435.04.

It is to cover this excess that the Rev. Principal now asks a grant.

With most of the arguments advanced by the principal I can heartily agree. I recently visited the school where he has already completed the erection of the building, a fine spacious one and he showed me the difference in some of the washing machinery between that supplied in the Eastern States of Canada and that manufactured in the U.S.A., and the comparison for strength and

K.W. Vowell Esq.,
Indian Supt. for B.C.

Victoria,
B.C.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6440, file 879-5, part 1)
durability was unquestionably in favour of the latter.

As to his remark about the higher cost of boilers in this province, that is due to the operation of a local statute known as "The Boiler Inspection Act." When this was first introduced (I was a member of the legislature at the time) the intention was simply to check accidents and ensure safety to those in charge but it has been amended so many times since and now it has almost become a measure of protection to B.C. boiler makers who possibly not so intended. A certain standard is required and this has been extended until a boiler has practically to be made in a certain prescribed way to pass. The local boiler makers who of course sell their whole output in B.C. know what the prescribed pattern is and build accordingly. The Eastern maker who manufactures for the whole of Canada produces a boiler in every respect as good but not in the prescribed pattern approved by the B.C. Act and after the boiler gets here to make the necessary changes would prove too costly. Consequently B.C. makers have a monopoly and prices are high.

I can heartily recommend Father Maurus' application to the favourable consideration of the Dept. The institution is a splendid testimonial to the ability of those in charge. From its first inception when funds were scarce indeed, its affairs have been managed by a far sighted and business like policy. Instead of a small building requiring to be eked out every now and then by a niggardly addition until an incoherent mass of petty buildings, as can be seen in some places, the Rev. Father decided on a broad comprehensive plan which he has gradually worked out as opportunity afforded until now he has a large institution admirably adapted in every way for its purpose and in which every modern convenience and economical arrangement can be made use of. The water supply for instance. Instead of having a small service to begin with which would be useless in a few years, he installed, at a considerably expense as it seemed at the time, a plant which will be sufficient for all time and for all enlargements of the school and which it is now easy
to see, was a most profitable investment in the first place.

So with the laundry I am satisfied that he is in the right in getting the best of machinery which will do the work satisfactorily and last long even though the initial cost be somewhat greater.

It must also be remembered that it is difficult to make estimates of what certain works will cost, two years before it is to be done as the cost of material is liable to vary a good deal within that period.

I may mention that with the exception of the two accounts already paid by the Dept., all the vouchers showing that the total sum named has been already expended or contracted for, are attached to a voucher in favor of the Rev. P. Maurus which I am forwarding by even mail under cover of my letter of 30th inst. No. 946-12, and which explains itself.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Since making the application two years ago for an allowance towards the erection and the equipment of a new laundry, most urgently needed, I sought occasions and availed myself of opportunities, to confer with experienced laundry men as well as to study the different kinds of laundry appliances and the method of their operation. From the observations and new knowledge gained I arrived at the conclusion that some of the appliances which I contemplated in the estimate, that would rather prove unpractical and little time and labor saving. Men experienced in the business strongly advised the use of steam and larger and stronger machinery. Hence I allowed myself to be guided by the experience and sound judgement of well-meaning friends and decided in favor of a steam laundry on a small scale.

There is another condition which affects an increase in the cost and of which I was utterly ignorant two years ago, and this is that some of the laundry appliances manufactured by Canadian concerns are much inferior to U.S. machinery, which however on account of duty come higher in price.

As to steam boiler this could be bought perhaps a hundred or more dollars cheaper in the East, but the B.C. laws will not allow eastern or U.S. makes in the province without almost impossible requirements, and B.C. boilers in consequence cost nearly twice as much outside makes.

I pray the Department most earnestly to allow our institution the additional grant to cover the excess of expenditure stated above.

I have the honor to remain, dear Mr. Agent,

Dear Sir,

We have long felt the need of a new barn. It was only because there was other still more urgent work to be done in previous years that this has not already been built.

The present barn, if we may call it so, is a place of patchwork, additions having been made to the original plan when land called for new buildings in years, cramped and the space is all together inadequate. We are very desirous to improve these conditions and intend to erect a new barn.

In the course of this matter, according to plans it will be 40 x 15 feet. It will give space for eight stalls and ample room for feedboxes, etc., and will serve the Indians as a model of a barn.

The lumber and other materials for this barn will cost $300.00 approximately. I most respectfully and also most earnestly ask the Department to meet this outlay as our needs are severely taxed otherwise, and I beg you to use your kind influence that this petition may be granted.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Yours obedient servant,

Sir:

I am planning how to have more land cleared and to improve the soil of the land already cleared but this requires hard work and a good deal of money - of the latter we have not sufficient and expect to be assisted by the Department. Ottawa, February 17, 1920.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th instant in further reference to your request for the payment of the travelling expenses in bringing children to the Christie Industrial School and also in returning them to their homes.

In reply I beg to say that, as previously informed, expenses of this nature are, in the cases of all residential schools, paid from the per capita grant. It is only in exceptional cases that the Department assumes responsibility for the payment of travelling expenses in bringing pupils to the schools, or in returning them to their homes. It might be well, in cases where pupils have to travel long distances and where the expenses are, therefore, correspondingly large, for such pupils to remain at the school during the summer holidays, in order to save unnecessary expense to the school in the payment of their transportation. The Department cannot assume any responsibility for the payment of the travelling expenses of bringing new pupils to your school, or of allowing them home for summer holidays.

Reverend and dear Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant, giving me information as to the condition of the buildings at the Christie industrial school, and asking that some assistance should be extended from funds at the disposal of the Department to improve them.

As you state, this property is owned by yourselves, and an understanding was arrived at some years ago by which the Department was not to be asked to accept any responsibility for buildings not owned by the Government, and that repairs and extensions were to be made by the Church authorities when they were found to be necessary.

I appreciate the financial position in which the Churches who are interested in Indian education find themselves at this time, but the same conditions apply to the Government, and I am constantly being requested by the Honourable the Superintendent General to limit demands upon the exchequer. Even if the title to the buildings were in the Department, it would be difficult to obtain the requisite monies for their improvement. I shall keep your necessities in view, and have given careful attention to your letter, and I regret that my present answer must needs be unfavourable.

B.C., Dec. 3rd 1920.

Dear Sir,

To understand this letter better, I am enclosing a photograph of our school building. The centre building was put up in 1879 and the two additions in 1904. Extensive repairs are now needed, and will be needed for the next few years. A new roof is badly needed—new. New floors, new baths, new (1500 gal.) water reservoir will be necessary in the near future. Painting and varnishing should be done over. The per capita grant does not cover anything for such like repairs.

Moreover we should have something of a gymnasium. This we cannot erect ourselves, but the material must come from somewhere else.

Both ground and buildings are owned by the Church; at the same time they are used only for the benefit and education of the Indians' children. It is true that in former years the Dept. has helped us by granting a special allowance for special purposes viz.
The building of the steam laundry and the water supply system.

I therefore earnestly request you that the Dept. again grant the moneys needed to keep our school in good repair and sanitary conditions, either by a special allowance for the separate repairs or by paying a yearly rent for the use of our buildings for the benefit and education of the Indian children.

I have spoken this matter over with Mr. Ditchburn last month, and he advised me to write to you personally.

Trusting that you will give this matter due consideration,

Yours obedient servant,
Clark Moore, A.B.,
Principal.

BUILDINGS.

The building has been painted on three sides since my visit one year ago. The roof now leaks in several places. It needs attention at once so that it may be in good shape before Autumn comes. It would be good economy to tar the roof or to paint it. The church owns the property, but the principal told me the church authorities are willing to turn the whole plant over to the Indian Department free of cost in order to have the buildings kept in repair. The school is doing a good work among these West Coast Indians. It would be a tragedy to let the building go to pieces which would lead to the closing of the school.

MEMORANDUM,

Mr. Scott,-

Mr. Agent Cox has forwarded an account for $235.67, the amount of the expenditure incurred by the Principal of the Christie Industrial School in the purchase of paint, oils, etc., which were used in the painting of the buildings at the school.

The Principal states that he obtained competitive prices before making the purchase of the paint, and I would recommend that, in view of the necessity of having the work done and the difficulty experienced by the Principal in financing the school under the conditions which exist as regards prices, the Department make an exception in this case and pay this account. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 23rd ultimo, enclosing vouchers for the fares of Indian children from the Christie Industrial School to their homes, and from their homes to the school, also correspondence which you had with the Principal regarding the payment of the transportation of these children.

In reply I beg to say that payment of these accounts is being made, and a cheque for $107.10 has been sent to the Principal.

In connection with the payment of the fares of Indian children to and from the school for the summer holidays, and in bringing new pupils to the school, I beg to say that in all cases where the parents are able to provide for the travelling expenses of their children they should be called upon to do so. While the Indian Act, Sub-section 3 of Section 9, states that the Superintendent General may provide the transportation, it is not the intention to pay indiscriminately in each case. The Principal should understand that, where parents are able to do so, it is expected that they will provide the cost of transportation expenses for their children. In cases of orphan and destitute children, where there is no one to provide their fares, the Department will undertake the payment.

You should inform the Principal that he should collect from the parents, when possible, sufficient funds to cover the cost of the transportation of their children to and from the school.

Your obedient servant,

CHRISTIE INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL.

At the time of my visit to Christie this summer, I found Father Calmus, the Principal, doing splendid work. He is busy from morning until night - administrating, teaching and supervising the boys' activities, even in the barns. Sister Caroline, the Superior, is a splendid type. She says Father Calmus is doing better than any of the late Principals.

The boys are not worked half enough, and the Principal is erecting a gymnasium to work off their surplus energy.

I advised the re-shingling of the roof and promised two sewing machines. We should pay part of the account for shingling.

The girls' dormitory was especially fine. There is a chair beside each bed - a splendid arrangement.

The water supply is adequate.

The property belongs to the O.S.B. Order, but if they withdrew it would revert to the Diocese. The land is all stumps and rocks, and there is no possible chance to farm, or to have a good garden. The Department should go slow taking over this property, as the land is so bad.

There is a very bright boy at this school by the name of Moses Smith, and the Department might do well to offer him tuition in a few years, upon graduation.

Mr. Agent Cox has not been at Christie for two years, and the Principal claims that Constable Bartlett has not been any help to them of late.

I understand Father Moser is going back to this vicinity as missionary.

This school has been very greatly improved during the last three or four years. I fail to see the necessity for six sets of carpenters tools for an institution of that size, for should six boys be in training at the same time, they would not necessarily all be using the same kind of tool at one and the same time, and some of the tools, although necessary in a kit, are very seldom used.

The price of a full kit of carpenters tools as specified on the attached list, at current prices is $45.80, but is subject to slight alteration.

Dear Sir:

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th ultimo, with reference to playground equipment for the Christie Indian Residential School. I wish to inform you, in reply, that to my knowledge no Indian residential school has seen fit to purchase and install such expensive equipment of this type, and I know that the Department has never assisted. It is doubtful if the benefits would be commensurate with the expense. The same amount of money, expended in other equipment over a term of years, would to my mind give far better service and satisfaction. Unless you repeat your request that the Department purchase for you and deduct from the per capita grant, no action to this end will be taken.

The Department wishes to assist you in your laudable efforts to provide suitable playground equipment for the children enrolled at the school. Volley ball and softball equipments are being ordered and will reach you in due course. No deduction will be made from the per capita grant.

Sir:

Re: Christie Industrial School,
Water Supply System and
Power Plant.

According to your instructions I made an inspection of the water system at the above mentioned school and investigated the possibilities of replacing the present system with one of larger capacity, to provide fire protection and power. I submit as follows:

CHRISTIE INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL

The school is situated on Meares Island in Clayoquot Sound on the West Coast of Vancouver Island. Clayoquot village, the nearest community, is several miles distant by water. The accompanying plan shows the layout of the school property. The buildings are all of frame construction and I am informed that the school population numbers about eighty.

PRESENT WATER SYSTEM

The source of the present water supply is Brother creek at a distance of about three-fourths of a mile from the school. A tank of about 10,000 gallons capacity forms a small reserve from which the school is supplied by a 2 inch iron pipe. The present supply is quite adequate for domestic purposes but affords practically no fire protection. The pipe is laid on the surface as I presume the cost of burying it at the time it was laid was considered too great. As a result it has suffered to some extent from corrosion but with some repairs would supply domestic requirements for some years.
yet. The present licence, C.L. 3453, held in the name of Christie school, is for 5000 gallons per day for domestic use.

SUPPLY OF WATER

Brother creek rises on the side of the mountain to the north of the school. It consists of a number of small springs which join together at a point immediately above the present intake. The flow, according to my information, has been fairly regular for the past ten years, although during an occasional dry year the supply becomes low. During the greater part of the year, however, the flow varies between 0.5 and 1.5 cubic feet per second.

The quality of the water is very good and no doubt it will remain unpolluted for many years as from the nature of the country it may be assumed that the watershed will remain uninhabited.

The supply of water is adequate for domestic use and for fire protection purposes.

WATER REQUIREMENTS

Water requirements for domestic use amount to approximately 5000 gallons per day and for fire protection purposes a supply of not less than 400 gallons per minute should be available to supply two fire streams. Application has been made to the provincial Water Rights Branch for the use of 350,000 gallons per day from Brother creek to supplement the present licence.

PROPOSED WATER SYSTEM

To replace the present system with one of sufficient capacity to provide adequate fire protection would cost $7875.00.

The accompanying plan shows the layout of
the scheme suggested.

The system proposed would have the same source of supply with a storage reserve of sufficient capacity to provide for two fire streams at low stage.

**FIRE PROTECTION**

For fire protection purposes a supply of 400 G.P.M. would be available at 53 lbs. pressure to outside hydrants and at slightly less pressure to those located inside the buildings.

The three outside hydrants are to be provided with small shelter houses and each equipped with 100 feet of 2½ inch hose and nozzle. The inside hydrants are placed two each on the lower two floors and a fifth on the third floor. To these are attached 50' lengths of 2 inch hose and nozzle, hung on hose racks.

**AUXILIARY POWER PLANT**

The new pipeline installation will provide 3.5 K.W. at very small additional cost. With an extension of the pipeline for 165 feet, a total effective head of 160 feet may be realized.

The present electric lighting plant, a 52 volt Delco, has outlived its usefulness, and has been replaced by a 5 K.W. Lister Standard lighting system, consisting of generator and battery set. This set, however, is expensive to operate and it is considered that a saving of $250.00 per year could be effected by the installation of a Pelton driven generator capable of using the surplus water for about 9 months in the year when the lighting load is heaviest. The gasoline plant under such conditions
might be used merely as a standby for battery charging purposes when the water reached very low stages. The cost of this extra electric plant would be $1400.00.

DETAILS OF PLANS

The storage works are to consist of a concrete reservoir 7'x16'x30', of 25,000 gallons capacity, built on the side hill to which it is proposed to divert the creek through a small screened settling basin adjoining the tank.

From the reservoir an 8 inch wood stave pipeline 3710' long is to be constructed to the school. The distribution pipes to hydrants are reduced to 6 inch wood stave and the domestic supply is provided for by three service pipes, one of 1½ inch and two of one inch. The inside hydrants are connected to the main line by 2½" iron pipe equipped with shut off valves. Provision is made for the extension of the pipe line to a powerhouse a short distance from the school.

Excavation for the pipe line will be expensive as there are numerous rock ridges to be crossed. The intermediate ground is mostly muskeg. In this it is proposed to lay the pipe on corduroy and provide the cover from borrow.

The cost of transportation of material will be high as large boats must stand off about one-fourth mile and lighter freight ashore. Shipment of material must be made in several consignments as facilities for handling are very limited.

The material will all have to be packed onto the job as there is no means of transportation available on the island.
The most suitable time for undertaking this work would be in midsummer as there is no accommodation at the school for the labor required. Transportation and working conditions will also be better at this season.

Herewith are attached plans and estimate of cost of the proposed works.

Your obedient servant,

SPECIFICATIONS

for

Installation of Water Supply System
and
Electric Light Plant
at
Christie School, Kakawin, V.I., B.C.
West Coast Indian Agency

Prepared for the Department of Indian Affairs
by
Dominion Water Power & Reclamation Service,
Vancouver, B.C.
C.E. Webb, District Chief Engineer,
August 1st, 1928.

PART I

THE CONTRACT

The bidder to whom an award is made shall execute a written contract with the Department of Indian Affairs, and, if bond is required, furnish good and approved bond within seven days after receiving the form of contract and bond for execution.

If the bidder to whom the award is made fails to enter into a contract as herein provided, the award will be cancelled, and an award may be made to the bidder whose proposal is the most acceptable in the opinion of the Department of Indian Affairs.

THE ENGINEER

The word "Engineer" used in these specifications or in the contract means the District Chief Engineer of the Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service, Vancouver, B.C., acting on behalf of the Department of Indian Affairs, who will be represented by an assistant or inspector authorized to act for him.

On all questions concerning the execution of the work and the determination of costs, the decision of the engineer shall be final.
THE CONTRACTOR

The word "Contractor" used in these specifications or in the contract means the person, firm or corporation with whom the contract is made by the Department of Indian Affairs.

The contractor shall, during the progress of the work, be represented on the works in person or by a foreman or duly designated agent, and instructions or information given by the engineer to the contractor, foreman or agent shall be considered as having been given to the contractor.

MATERIAL AND WORKMANSHIP

All materials other than tools of the contractor will be delivered f.o.b. lighter at Christie School beach by the Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service. Reasonable notice as to materials required but not covered by these specifications must be given to the engineer by the contractor.

The contractor will supply all tools required for the excavation, backfilling, grubbing, clearing and construction of concrete work.

All tools required for the fitting of pipes and parts thereof will be supplied by the Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service.

All work shall be done and completed in a thorough and workmanlike manner notwithstanding any omission from these specifications or drawings.

All work done must be satisfactory to the engineer; work not in accordance with these specifications in the opinion of the engineer, shall be made to conform thereto.

DELAYS

The contractor shall receive no compensation for delays or hindrances to the work except when in the judgment of the engineer, direct or unavoidable extra cost to the contractor is caused by the failure of the Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service to provide necessary information or materials for the installation.

All decisions of the engineer with regard to any claims for compensation shall be accepted by the contractor and regarded by him as final.

CHANGES

The engineer may, upon notice to the contractor, make such changes in the designs and materials supplied as the engineer may deem advisable; if such changes result in an increase or decrease of cost to the contractor the engineer will make such additions or reductions on account thereof as he may deem reasonable and proper, and his action shall be final.
EXTRA WORK

In connection with the work covered by this contract the engineer may order work not covered by these specifications. Such work will be classed as extra work and will be ordered in writing. No extra work will be paid for unless ordered in writing and only at the rate or amount fixed upon in the written order.

Solid rock excavation shall be extra to this contract and shall be paid for at the bid price of the contractor.

INSPECTION

All work done in this contract will be subject to inspection.

All work that does not conform to the specifications accepted through oversight or otherwise may be rejected at any stage of the work.

ERRORS AND OMISSIONS

The contractor will not be allowed to take advantage of any error or omission in these specifications; suitable instructions will be given where an error or omission is discovered.

SPECIFICATIONS AND DRAWINGS

The engineer will furnish the contractor with such detail plans and information as he may consider necessary for the contractor's guidance.

DAMAGES

The contractor will be held responsible and required to make good, at his own expense, all damages to person or property caused by carelessness or neglect on the part of the contractor, his agent or employees.

CHARACTER OF WORKMEN

The contractor shall not allow his agent or employees to trespass on lands or premises in the vicinity of the work; and shall, when required by the engineer, discharge any person in his employ who is, in the opinion of the engineer, disorderly, dangerous, incompetent or objectionable.

METHOD AND APPLIANCES

The method and appliances adopted by the contractor shall be such as will, in the opinion of the engineer, secure satisfactory quality of work and enable the contractor to complete the work in the time agreed upon.

PROTECTION

The contractor shall be responsible for all material furnished him and for the care of all work until its completion and final acceptance.
The contractor will be responsible for the safety of all men engaged upon the work and shall adopt such methods of construction as will ensure their well-being, and shall accept full liability for all damage units, claims for compensation, etc., arising out of any injury to an employee working under his control.

COMPLETION OF WORK

The contractor shall complete the work in the time agreed in this contract and shall, upon its completion remove all plant, rubbish or unused material at his own expense.

PART II

Work to be performed by contractor.

CLEARING

Sufficient land is to be cleared so that the pipe line may be properly laid in accordance with the attached plan.

Such additional clearing as may be directed by the engineer to provide for the safety of the works constructed shall be carried out as part of this contract.

DAM, RESERVOIR AND POWER HOUSE FOUNDATIONS

A concrete dam, foundations for settling tank, reservoir and power house will be constructed at points shown on the plans. The concrete used is to be properly mixed and of proportions to pass compression test of 2500 lbs. per sq. inch after 28 days under standard testing methods.

EXCAVATION FOR PIPE AND BACKFILLING

Sufficient excavation will be done so that all pipes may be properly laid and not less than one and one-half feet of cover provided.

LAYING PIPE, INSTALLING HYDRANTS, VALVES AND FITTINGS

The pipe and pertinent parts shown on the attached plans are to be laid in a proper manner; all pipe to be subjected to a test for leaks before being covered. Connections to all service pipes are to be made as shown on plan.

RESERVOIRS AND SETTLING TANK

The reservoir and settling tank are to be erected according to accompanying plan. Sufficient excavation will be made to assure substantial foundation.
INSIDE HYDRANTS AND SUPPLY PIPE

The inside hydrants are to be placed one on each floor level at a height of 6 feet above floor. Horizontal pipes are to be securely fastened to overhead beams and vertical pipes securely fastened to walls.

OUTSIDE HYDRANTS

Outside hydrants are to be set at a depth of 3 feet in the ground and to be equipped with covers having doors with fastenings.

POWER HOUSE

The power house is to be built according to attached plan and securely fastened to foundation as shown.

WOODWORK

All wood surfaces are to be given two coats of paint.

POWER LINE

The power line is to be erected as shown on plan. The poles are to be buried to a depth of five feet and must be pointed and painted on top end, side brackets to be securely fastened. The wires are to be securely fastened to insulators in approved manner. The exit and entrance of building shall be made through porcelain conduit.

WIRING

The necessary wiring shall be done in accordance with provincial wiring regulations, connections to all service lines to be made as shown on plan.

TIME ALLOWANCE AND PAYMENT FOR WORK

Work shall be commenced by the contractor within ten (10) days and shall be completed thirty (30) days after the execution of the contract on behalf of the Department of Indian Affairs.

The Contractor shall, at all times during the continuation of the contract, prosecute the work with such force and equipment as in the judgment of the Engineer are sufficient to complete it within the specified time.

Upon completion of the work, due notice shall be given by the contractor to the Engineer inspecting the work, and, if same is found to be satisfactory, payment will be made from the office of the District Chief Engineer, Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service at Vancouver, acting on behalf of the Department of Indian Affairs, within a reasonable time from date of its inspection.
SUMMARY

The contractor hereby agrees to carry out the work necessary in accordance with the said plans and specifications for a total of $2300.00 and in addition to excavate such solid rock as shall be designated by the engineer at a price of $4.00 per cubic yard.

The contractor furthermore guarantees that the above work, when completed by him, shall conform as nearly as possible, in all respects, to the requirement and details laid down in these plans and specifications.
