November 15, 1928.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 9th inst. with reference to project at Christie School, I beg to inform you that the engineer who has had charge of this work is at present in the field and hence it is impossible for me to immediately give you the detailed information required. However, upon his return to Vancouver I will endeavour to obtain the desired information.

As stated in my letter of November 7th the labour on this project is being carried out under contract by A. Thomason. The work was not advertised. The element of time was a governing factor as it was most desirable that the work should be undertaken and completed before the wet season set in. Thomason had just completed a similar job satisfactorily for us and as he agreed to immediately undertake this work at what we considered a reasonable figure, he was immediately instructed to proceed.

I now realize your position in the matter and regret very much that the job was not advertised in your locality, even though considerable delay might have been occasioned in the commencement of the work. I can assure you however, that we have endeavoured to act, in this and every other project, in the best interests of the Government.

There is a possibility that this service may have charge of the installation of water and sewer systems for the new Indian school at Alert Bay and I would appreciate hearing from you as to your opinion where best to advertise the labour for this work in that locality. You will realize, however, in work of this kind the skilled labour is required for a great deal of the work which includes laying of pipes and fittings and construction of reinforced concrete reservoirs, manholes, etc.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) C. E. Webb,
District Chief Engineer.

A.W. Neill, Esq., M.P.,
Alberni, B.C.
November 16, 1928.

Sir,

In reference to your enquiry regarding the letting of the labour contract for the water and light systems installed at Christie school, Kakawis, I wish to inform you that contrary to the usual procedure bids were not advertised for. I believe, however, the course followed was in the best interests of the work and of the Department of Indian Affairs.

Earlier in the season tenders had been submitted for material for this work in anticipation of commencing about the 15th of July, with the idea of carrying it out either by day labour or contract labour, whichever appeared at the time most suitable. However, owing to the pressure of other work on which the Department of Indian Affairs were pressing for immediate action the commencement of the work was delayed until the 1st of September. At this time I found myself with at least half of my season's programme of work unfinished. In consequence of which no further delay could be considered if the Christie school work was to be completed before the wet weather made it impossible to secure a satisfactory job. I was fortunate in securing the services of Mr. Thomason, who had given such satisfactory service on the Mission School project, to undertake the work at the estimated cost for labour.

I may say that Mr. Thomason could not complete the work within the contract period of thirty days owing to the weather conditions and the impossibility of securing sufficient labour locally. Before Mr. Thomason commenced the work he spent several days in Alberni looking for men but none were available either there or at Nanaimo.

The following information has been furnished me by the contractor from his payroll in regard to men employed by him:

| Name                  | Days |
|-----------------------|------|
| Peter Bremen, Tofino  | 54   |
| Col. Nelson, Tofino   | 6    |
| Fritz Bonette, Long Beach | 29 |
| Fred David, Tofino    | 7    |
| 6 Indians at various times, Tofino | 42 |

Total 120 man-days.

The total man days on the work was 365. You will note that about 40% of the labour was employed locally.

Your obedient servant,

C.E. Webb, Esq.,

Alberni, Nov. 9th, 1928.

C.E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
739 Hastings Street, West,
Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Sir,

I have your letter of 7th inst. No. 33615-5. I note the labor was contracted at a cost of $2300.00 to a Vancouver firm. May I ask whether this contract was put up to competition and if so how and where was it advertised in this district?

There are plenty of men and firms able to tender on such jobs in this district. I have never found any people resident in this district being given an opportunity of tendering for work in Vancouver nor do we expect it but the converse is surely no more than fair?

I see it is stated that the contractor employed labour hired locally. I would like to be told how many men he so employed, where he got them and for how long they were employed.

You know how touchy people are at outsiders being brought in to do work when they are unemployed.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd.) A. W. Neill.

Sir,

Sir:

I wish to refer to your 28/28 of April 12th last, with reference to the fire escapes at the Christie Indian Residential School. The new Principal, Rev. Victor Rassier, O.S.B., writes that the fire escape leading from the boys' dormitory window is a ladder and that if the stairways are cut off it might be unsafe for the small boys. I should be pleased if you would let me have a report and recommendation in this connection.

The Principal also states that certain improvements are necessary to the heating plant. I have informed him that there are no funds for this purpose or for replacing the washing machine; but, if you have any information relative to these requests, you might let the Department have a report.

March 7, 1929.

Sir:

Re: Christie School Water Supply and Electric Light Plant.

I have to inform you that the works in connection with the above mentioned systems have been installed as provided for in Mr. Warren's report of March 5, 1928.

The works as proposed were installed with the exception of the concrete storage tank. This was altered to a wooden tank in order to maintain the cost of work within the estimate. The life of the wood tank will be in excess of that of the pipe line and a considerably saving was effected.

The system was tested out and worked satisfactorily. The hydrants supplied sufficient water at a good pressure to completely cover the school buildings.

The electric lighting plant developed 3.2 k.w. and was of sufficient capacity to operate all the lights in the school. It will be operated in conjunction with a battery plant already installed, additional equipment being provided for this purpose.

The cost of the completed system was $9075.46 against an estimated cost of $9275.00. Final accounts were submitted with my letter of the 19th ult.

April 17, 1929.

Dear Sir:

Permit me to thank you for your valued favor No. 159-0-11, under date of the 3d instant. I am very grateful to the Department for the sewing machines and for the cooperation and assistance it promises me in the matter of manual training. In accordance with the recommendations contained in your letter I will, as soon as I have given more thought and study to the matter, submit to Mr. Frost a detailed list and estimated cost of what is required to carry out our program of instruction in carpentry and internal combustion and marine engines. If it will be possible, I am quite certain, to have the same instructor handle both classes.

May I respectfully request the Department to reconsider the number of sewing machines it has seen fit to send the Christie School? It seems to me, there must be some misunderstanding. The matter was gone over very carefully by the Indian Agent, Mr. Frost, and myself with the Sister in charge of our sewing department, and we cut down our needs to the very limit of what was deemed necessary to carry on the class efficiently and without disorganizing seriously the girls' department—so easily done because of the unsatisfactory conditions here and over which we have no control.

Furthermore, in taking over this position, I am most desirous to train our boys and girls well in the work they will be called upon to do after leaving school; and I can't conceive, after the encouraging tone of your letter as regards training of boys in their subjects, the Department handicapping me in my efforts for the girls for the sake of two sewing machines, unless there be some misunderstanding.

And it is only because I feel certain that there is a misunderstanding that I am making bold to trouble the Department to rehear the situation. I am sure after this explanation it will reconsider the matter and oblige the school as per my original request.

Mr. Frost visited the school recently in company with a plumbing expert. His report will, no doubt, reach you shortly. I am sure that if Mr. Frost presents the situation as he found it, which I have no reason to believe he will not, it will be evident to the Department what real suffering and hardship were undergone by the children during the months of February and March when the heating system in the school ceased to function and was pronounced beyond repair by those called in to make repairs.

I do not hesitate to say that to compel these children to endure another winter of such misery would be nothing short of criminal. And that is precisely what will happen unless the Department takes action. The school itself is simply unable to remedy the situation because of the financial embarrassment created...

Gentlemen,

After careful consideration of the conditions existing at Christie School, Nakawis, B.C., I have with the Principal, Father Hassler, reached the conclusion that the Government must come to our aid.

1.-The present school is a fire-trap and has not even the necessary fireplaces.

2.-The school is out of date and entirely unsuited for the purpose of a first-class school with proper classes, and especially for manual training.

3.-A new site is required and a new school to carry on the necessary work of education.

The enclosed letter from Father Hassler will I hope meet with the approval of the Department.

April 19, 1929.

Gentlemen:

I feel it my duty as the new Principal of Christie Indian Residential School to place before the Department for its consideration the following facts:

At this writing the school is in arrears to the amount of over $8,000.00. Half of this indebtedness embraces grocery, feed, repair bills unpaid; the other half, salary obligations unfulfilled.

My predecessor in office installed a water system with the consent of the Department costing $6,275.00—the institution paying $5,275.00, the Department $4,000.00 of the cost.

He also installed a lighting system at a cost of $5,000.00, which, there is sufficient evidence on hand to prove, was an absolute necessity.

This is precisely the extent of the school's indebtedness. The correspondence with the Department on file in this office seems to indicate that the Department would have conducted and paid the cost of both installations, had it been approached in the proper manner.

It requires no argument from me to demonstrate that the institution, being saddled with this indebtedness, is working a discouraging hardship on the staff, is interfering with the work of the school, and, to the extent that it is depriving them of the attention and care they have a right to from the school to which the Department directs them, it is inflicting an injustice upon the Catholic Indian children of this agency.

What I would ask of the Department is, will it not take steps at once to refund the amount involved? To refuse to do so, it appears to me, is to punish the staff and the children for the error in procedure which my predecessor apparently committed, since, in its last analysis, that would seem to be all that stands between the school being in debt and out of debt.

Truly yours,

Victor Rassiar, O.S.B.

Dear Sir:

Report on Christie School Kakawis, B.C. The heating boiler is worn out past repair and will have to be replaced by sectional boiler. The new addition to the school is not properly heated. The ground floor has a fireplace with coils in it; by this means the water for the radiator on the first floor is heated, this is very unsatisfactory. Flow and return mains should be run from the heating boiler to the new addition. Radiators put in on the ground floor and coupled up with the radiators on the first floor.

The shower baths in the basketball hall should be removed to the boys basement.

The boys closets should be re-arranged so that they do not open on the hall way between the kitchen and boys dining room.

The present plumbing is badly in need of a general overhaul. Two broken closet bowls and tanks also several seats should be replaced by new ones and several new basin taps.

There is no septic tank to take care of the discharge from the drains, all empties into a small stream close by the school and is causing a nuisance. A septic tank should be built large enough to take care of the school, with a 200 foot discharge drain. This tank and drain could be built by the larger boys.

The laundry machine is past repairing, it is full of rotten holes and will have to be replaced by a new one. A Simplex Ironer should be installed at the same time, hand ironing is too slow for a school of this size, especially where the irons have to be heated on a stove.

Two large hot water tanks should be installed in the main building, for the baths and basins, and one in the laundry. There is a 30 gallon boiler in the laundry now, it does not hold enough water to half fill the washing machine.

The new boiler, radiators, fittings, and flange unions to connect the new boiler to present system, valves on the flow and return mains to control different sections of the plant, the installing of the new boiler, cutting up of the old boiler to get it out of the basement, changing the shower baths and the boys closets, two hot water tanks, new washing machine and ironer, overhauling the plumbing and radiation in the new addition will cost approximately three thousand nine hundred twenty-five dollars, $3925.00. Material F.O.B., C.P.R. steamer at Kakawis.

Yours truly, (sd) A.S. Hanna,

Memorandum:

HONOURABLE CHARLES STEWART.

On the west coast of Vancouver Island, near Clayoquot Sound, there is situated the Christie Indian Residential School, conducted by the Benedictine Fathers. The school was established by the Church over 50 years ago, and it has continuously served the Indians of the west coast.

It is only lately that the Department has given any assistance, other than per capita grant. A year ago, there was an item of $4,000 in the Indian Education Appropriation, to provide water supply, fire protection and electric light plant. Approximately $1,000 towards this improvement was to be provided by the Church - the first estimate being $5,000. The Department asked the Dominion Water Power Branch to make a report, and they found that $9,300 was required. The Reverend Principal was asked to provide $5,000 for the purpose, which was the amount necessary over and above the vote. The final arrangement was that the Department was to pay for the improvement and that $5,075.46 was to be deducted, by instalments, from the per capita grant.

In February, last, Reverend Father Victor, O.S.B., was appointed Principal, and he has made a real effort to grapple with the problems of the school and to serve our Roman Catholic wards on the west coast. He finds that the deductions from the per capita grant have crippled the school financially, and further, that some improvements now must be made to the heating plant. I have been very favourably impressed by Father Victor, and, as funds are available in the current Appropriation to assist, I wish to recommend that he be relieved from this obligation to repay the $5,075.46 and that approximately $2,500 be expended in the necessary improvements to mechanical plant. The last mentioned work could be undertaken by Mr. A. S. Hanna, plumbing contractor of Alberni, who has been suggested by Mr. A. W. Neill, M.P.

This recommendation is in harmony with the policy of the past few years. When a modern school cannot be erected for some time, the old building has been made as safe and comfortable as funds will permit. The Christie School is educating 100 children in residence and is an important factor in our programme for the advancement of British Columbia Indians.

Deputy Superintendent General.
